page.title: 50 Things That Made the Modern Economy

revision.comment: Corrected item 51 to Number 51 and added actual tagline as used by BBC. Corrected and expanded 51st thing explanation
revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=August 2017}}
'''50 Things That Made the Modern Economy''' began as a weekly economic history [[Radio documentary|documentary radio]] series on the [[BBC World Service]] presented by economist and journalist [[Tim Harford]]. The first episode was broadcast on Saturday 5 November 2016, and all episodes are available as [[podcast]]s.
Harford explained his motivation "to paint a picture of economic change by telling the stories of the ideas, people, and tools that had far-reaching consequences". He was fascinated by the many unexpected outcomes, such as "the impact of the fridge on global politics, or of the gramophone on income inequality."<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/mediacentre/latestnews/2017/51st-thing-that-made-the-modern-economy "BBC World Service invites suggestions for the ’51st Thing’ that made the modern economy"], ''[[BBC World Service]]'', 19 August 2017. Retrieved on 10 September 2017.</ref>
The series was subsequently released by Harford as a book titled '''Fifty Things That Made The Modern Economy''' in the UK published by [[Little, Brown Book Group|Little, Brown Books]], and as '''Fifty Inventions That Shaped The Modern Economy''' in the US published by [[Riverhead Books]]. The hardcover and eBook editions were released on 6 July 2017 in the UK and the US edition was released on 29 August 2017. A paperback edition has been announced for May 2018.
A public call was made for suggestions for a '''51st thing''' in August 2017. Harford chose his six favourite submissions for an online vote from late September to 6 October 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/articles/4Y4Gn8gbQvp4X87wGLV3n4N/vote-for-the-51st-thing|title=Vote for the 51st Thing!|last=|first=|date=|website=BBC|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171005133320/http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/articles/4Y4Gn8gbQvp4X87wGLV3n4N/vote-for-the-51st-thing|archive-date=5 October 2017|dead-url=|access-date=5 October 2017}}</ref> The winning item was announced as the [[Credit Card]] in an episode released on 28 October 2017.
==Radio series==
Each of the nine-minute long programmes introduces the story of fifty products or inventions that have revolutionised the modern world.
Each episode was originally broadcast on BBC World Service, with a subsequent broadcast on [[BBC Radio 4]] and distribution as a BBC podcast.
{| class="wikitable" |+ style="text-align: left;" | Episode listing with released titles and taglines |- ! scope="col" | Episode !! scope="col" | Title !! scope="col" | Tagline !! scope="col" | Broadcast Date |- ! scope="row" | 1 | [[Diesel engine|Diesel Engine]] || Rudolf Diesel died in strange circumstances after changing the world with his engine || 5 Nov 2016 |- ! scope="row" | 2 | [[Haber process|Haber-Bosch Process]] || Saving lives with thin air - by taking nitrogen from the air to make fertiliser || 14 Nov 2016 |- ! scope="row" | 3 | [[Intermodal container|Shipping Container]] || The boom in global trade was caused by a simple steel box || 19 Nov 2016 |- ! scope="row" | 4 | [[Concrete]] || It's improved health, school attendance, agricultural productivity and farm worker wages || 26 Nov 2016 |- ! scope="row" | 5 | [[iPhone]] || How Uncle Sam played an essential role in the creation and development of the iPhone || 3 Dec 2016 |- ! scope="row" | 6 | [[Barcode]] || How vast mega-stores emerged with the help of a design originally drawn in the sand || 10 Dec 2016 |- ! scope="row" | 7 | [[Bank]]ing || Warrior monks, crusaders and the mysterious origins of modern banking || 17 Dec 2016 |- ! scope="row" | 8 | [[Electric light|Lightbulb]] || Once too precious to use, light is now too cheap to notice || 24 Dec 2016 |- ! scope="row" | 9 | [[M-Pesa]] || Transferring money by text message is far safer and more convenient than cash || 31 Dec 2016 |- ! scope="row" | 10 | [[Compiler]] || Installing Windows might take 5,000 years without it || 7 Jan 2017 |- ! scope="row" | 11 | [[Billy (bookcase)|Billy Bookcase]] || Low cost, functional and brilliantly efficient, one is produced every three seconds || 14 Jan 2017 |- ! scope="row" | 12 | [[Antibiotics]] || The tale of antibiotics is a cautionary one, and economic incentives are often to blame || 20 Jan 2017 |- ! scope="row" | 13 | [[Paper]] || The Gutenberg press changed the world – but it could not have done so without paper || 28 Jan 2017 |- ! scope="row" | 14 | [[Insurance]] || Insurance is as old as gambling, but it’s fundamental to the way the modern economy works || 4 Feb 2017 |- ! scope="row" | 15 | [[Google Search|Google]] || The words 'clever' and 'death' crop up less often than 'Google' in conversation || 11 Feb 2017 |- ! scope="row" | 16 | [[Clock]] || The clock was invented in 1656 and has become an essential part of the modern economy || 18 Feb 2017 |- ! scope="row" | 17 | [[Safety razor|Disposable Razor]] || King Camp Gillette created the disposable razor. But his influence extends beyond shaving || 25 Feb 2017 |- ! scope="row" | 18 | [[Robot]] || Robots threaten the human workforce, but they are crucial to the modern economy || 4 Mar 2017 |- ! scope="row" | 19 | [[Public-key cryptography|Public-Key Cryptography]] || Geeks versus government – the story of public key cryptography || 11 Mar 2017 |- ! scope="row" | 20 | [[Battery (electricity)|Battery]] || The story of the battery begins inside a dead murderer. It’s a tale that’s far from over || 18 Mar 2017 |- ! scope="row" | 21 | [[Phonograph|Gramophone]] || "Superstar” economics – the story of how the gramophone led to a winner-take-all market || 25 Mar 2017 |- ! scope="row" | 22 | [[TV dinner|TV Dinner]] || The TV dinner, and other inventions from the same era, made a lasting economic impression || 1 Apr 2017 |- ! scope="row" | 23 | [[Oral contraceptive pill|Contraceptive Pill]] || The pill wasn’t just socially revolutionary, it also sparked an economic revolution || 8 Apr 2017 |- ! scope="row" | 24 | [[Elevator]] || The safety elevator is a mass transit system that has changed the shape of our cities || 15 Apr 2017 |- ! scope="row" | 25 | [[Air conditioning|Air Conditioning]] || Invented for the printing industry, air conditioning now influences where and how we live || 22 Apr 2017 |- ! scope="row" | 26 | [[Cuneiform script|Cuneiform]] || Cuneiform, the earliest known script, was used to create the world’s first accounts || 29 Apr 2017 |- ! scope="row" | 27 | [[Video game|Video Games]] || From Spacewar to Pokemon Go, video games have shaped the modern economy in surprising ways || 6 May 2017 |- ! scope="row" | 28 | [[Intellectual property|Intellectual Property]] || Intellectual property reflects an economic trade off when it comes to innovation || 13 May 2017 |- ! scope="row" | 29 | [[Passport]]s || If anyone could work anywhere, some economists think global economic output would double || 22 May 2017 |- ! scope="row" | 30 | [[Tally stick|Tally Stick]] || The tally stick shows us what money really is: a kind of debt that can be traded freely || 27 May 2017 |- ! scope="row" | 31 | [[Index fund|Index Fund]] || Warren Buffett is one of the world’s great investors. His advice? Invest in an index fund || 3 Jun 2017 |- ! scope="row" | 32 | [[Infant formula|Infant Formula]] || For many new mothers who want, or need, to get back to work, infant formula is a godsend || 10 Jun 2017 |- ! scope="row" | 33 | [[Tax haven|Tax Havens]] || Gabriel Zucman invented an ingenious way to estimate how much wealth is hidden offshore || 17 Jun 2017 |- ! scope="row" | 34 | [[Barbed wire|Barbed Wire]] || “Lighter than air, stronger than whiskey” – barbed wire wreaked huge changes in America || 24 Jun 2017 |- ! scope="row" | 35 | [[Department store|Department Store]] || Harry Selfridge pioneered a whole new retail experience with his London department store || 1 Jul 2017 |- ! scope="row" | 36 | [[Gasoline#Tetraethyllead|Leaded Petrol]] || When lead was added to petrol it made cars more powerful – but it also poisoned people || 8 Jul 2017 |- ! scope="row" | 37 | [[Dynamo]] || The big story behind the way dynamos made electricity useful || 15 Jul 2017 |- ! scope="row" | 38 | [[Limited liability company|Limited Liability Company]] || How some legal creativity has created vast wealth down the centuries || 22 Jul 2017 |- ! scope="row" | 39 | [[Banknote|Paper Money]] || Currency derives value from trust in the government which issues it || 29 Jul 2017 |- ! scope="row" | 40 | [[Reputation system|Seller Feedback]] || Without seller feedback, companies like eBay might not have grown as they have || 5 Aug 2017 |- ! scope="row" | 41 | [[Plastic]] || We make so much plastic these days that it takes about eight percent of oil production || 12 Aug 2017 |- ! scope="row" | 42 | [[Market research|Market Research]] || Market research marked a shift from a producer-led to consumer-led approach to business || 19 Aug 2017 |- ! scope="row" | 43 | [[Radar]] || A high-tech ‘death ray’ capable of zapping sheep led to the invention of radar || 26 Aug 2017 |- ! scope="row" | 44 | [[Trap (plumbing)|S-Bend]] || The S-bend was a pipe with a curve in it, an invention that led to public sanitation || 2 Sep 2017 |- ! scope="row" | 45 | [[Double-entry bookkeeping system|Double-entry Bookkeeping]] || Market research marked a shift from a producer-led to consumer-led approach to business || 9 Sep 2017 |- ! scope="row" | 46 | [[Management consulting|Management Consulting]] || If managers often have a bad reputation, what should we make of the people who tell managers how to manage?|| 16 Sep 2017 |- ! scope="row" | 47 | [[Land registration|Property Register]] || Property rights for the world's poor could unlock trillions in ‘dead capital’|| 30 Sep 2017 |- ! scope="row" | 48 | [[Welfare state|Welfare State]] || Do welfare states boost economic growth, or stunt it? It’s not an easy question to answer|| 7 Sep 2017 |- ! scope="row" | 49 | [[Cold chain|Cold Chain]] || Refrigeration revolutionised the food industry, and other industries too|| 14 Oct 2017 |- ! scope="row" | 50 | [[Plough]] || The plough kick-started civilisation - and ultimately made our modern economy possible|| 21 Oct 2017 |- ! scope="row" | 51 | Number 51 || Revealed – the winning 51st Thing! Which “thing” won the vote to be added to our list? || 28 Oct 2017 |}
==51st Thing==
The shortlist selected by Tim Harford for public vote as the 51st thing was: * [[Credit Card]] * [[Glass]] * [[Global Positioning System|Global Positioning System (GPS)]] * [[Irrigation]] * [[Pencil|The Pencil]] * [[Spreadsheet]]
The item selected by public vote was the [[Credit Card]], announced by Tim Harford in the episode entitled “Number 51”
==Book Chapters==
Each of the short chapters describes fifty products or inventions that have revolutionised the modern world.
The book title uses the word Fifty whereas the radio programme uses the number 50. The chapter order is different to the radio broadcast and podcast order, some book chapters have modified titles, and the chapters are grouped into sections in the book.

{{Orphan|date=November 2018}} {{Infobox galaxy | name = A1689B11 | image = | caption = False-color image of A1689B11 | epoch = [[J2000]] | constellation name = [[Virgo (constellation)|Virgo]] | ra = {{RA|13|11|33.336}} | dec = {{DEC|-01|21|06.9}} | z = 2.540 | h_radial_v = | dist_ly = | group_cluster = | type = S | mass = 1010.2 (dynamical)
109.8 ± 0.3 (stellar) | appmag_v = | appmag_b = | half_light_radius_pc = 2600 ± 700 pc | size_v = | notes = | names = BBC2005 11.1, [BBC2005] Source 11 }} '''A1689B11''' is an extremely old [[spiral galaxy]] located in the [[Abell 1689]] galaxy cluster in the Virgo constellation.{{cite web|title=[BBC2005] Source 11 -- Galaxy|url=http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-basic?Ident=%5BBBC2005%5D+Source+11&submit=SIMBAD+search|date=24 June 2018}} The disk of A1689B11 is cool and thin, yet it produced stars at thirty times the rate of the Milky Way. A1689B11 is 11 billion light years from the Earth, forming 2.6 billion years after the Big Bang. It is the most distant known and earliest spiral galaxy {{as of|2017|lc=y}}.{{cite web|title=The most ancient spiral galaxy confirmed|url=https://phys.org/news/2017-11-ancient-spiral-galaxy.html|publisher=PhysOrg|date=3 November 2017}}{{cite journal|publisher=|arxiv=1710.11130|title=The most ancient spiral galaxy: a 2.6-Gyr-old disk with a tranquil velocity field|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|volume=850|pages=61|author1=Tiantian Yuan|author2=Johan Richard|author3=Anshu Gupta|author4=Christoph Federrath|author5=Soniya Sharma|author6=Brent A. Groves|author7=Lisa J. Kewley|author8=Renyue Cen|author9=Yuval Birnboim|author10=David B. Fisher|date=30 October 2017|doi=10.3847/1538-4357/aa951d|bibcode=2017ApJ...850...61Y}} ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Spiral galaxies]] [[Category:Virgo (constellation)]] {{galaxy-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Use British English|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox road |country=GBR |type=A |route=307 |subtype=minor |image=TD 05-09-170242.JPG |image_notes=The A307 Portsmouth Road running through Thames Ditton. |length_mi= 13.2 |direction_a= North |terminus_a = [[Kew]] |direction_b= South |terminus_b = [[Cobham, Surrey|Cobham]] |junction = {{ukroadsmall|205}}

{{ukroadsmall|240}}

{{ukroadsmall|309}}
{{ukroadsmall|244}}

{{ukroadsmall-svg|3}} |destinations= [[Richmond, London|Richmond]], [[Kingston upon Thames]] }} {{TOClimit|2}} The '''A307 road''' runs {{convert|13.2|mi|km}} through SW London and NW Surrey. It is primary at the north-east end; the remainder is non-primary, generally superseded in the mid-twentieth century in two stages by newer alignments of the [[Portsmouth Road]], the Kingston bypass and Esher bypass of the [[A3 road (Great Britain)|A3 road]] which runs along a slightly oblique axis. ==Route== ===London Borough of Richmond Upon Thames, Greater London - Kew and Richmond=== It begins at the junction with the A205 South Circular Road beside [[Kew|Kew Green]] {{nowrap|({{coord|51.4827|-0.2869|type:landmark_region:GB|display=inline|name=A307 road (northern end)}})}}, where it is named Kew Road. It then runs towards [[Richmond, London|Richmond upon Thames or Richmond, London]], through the west of Kew. At the junction with the A316 in Richmond it becomes a non-primary A-road through the town centre then heads through [[Petersham, London|Petersham]] where for fewer than 100 metres it kinks west and then travels south through [[Ham, London|Ham]]. A [[B roads in Zone 3 of the Great Britain numbering scheme|B-class road]], the B353, leaves the A307 in Kew and runs around the town centre and up Richmond Hill and by-passing Richmond, before rejoining the A307 at Petersham. ===Royal Borough of Kingston Upon Thames, Greater London - Kingston upon Thames, Surbiton and part of Long Ditton=== It bisects the north of the town before becoming the western half of the one-way system in [[Kingston upon Thames]]. Here it is briefly merged with the A308. It leads south to the northern end of the [[A240 road|A240]], for 200m travels west to the River Thames, and resuming south becomes at last the old version of the [[Portsmouth Road]] (which is also its name here). It runs next to the [[River Thames]], heading through [[Surbiton, London, England|Surbiton]]. It passes a junction with the A243, shortly before exiting the borough at [[Seething Wells]] there next to [[Long Ditton]]. ===Thames Ditton, Esher and Cobham, Surrey=== The Thames which is curved alongside [[Thames Ditton]] veers away from its now almost straight south-west course; the road passes through [[Hinchley Wood]], going through the [[Scilly Isles, Surrey|Scilly Isles roundabout]] with the [[A309 road|A309]]. It forms the [[High Street]] of [[Esher]], crosses the A3 (new Portsmouth Road) by way of a bridge north of Cobham, before terminating near a junction of the A3 in [[Cobham, Surrey|Cobham]] {{nowrap|({{coord|51.3321|-0.4178|type:landmark_region:GB|display=inline|name=A307 road (southern end)}}),}} which is generally also known as Portsmouth Road. ==Landmarks on the route== [[File:Kingston St Raphael's-1.jpg|thumb|Surbiton's Roman Catholic church of Saint Raphael]] *Victoria Gate, an entrance to [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew|Kew Gardens]] *[[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew#Marianne North Gallery|Marianne North Gallery]] *[[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew#Pagoda|Kew Gardens Pagoda]] *[[London Welsh RFC|London Welsh]] rugby ground at [[Old Deer Park]] *[[Richmond station (London)|Richmond railway station]] *[[Richmond, London#Richmond Riverside|Richmond Old Town Hall]] *[[Richmond Brewery Stores]] *[[Richmond Hill, London|Richmond Hill]] *[[Richmond Park]] *[[Dysart Arms|The Dysart]] *Gates of [[Montrose House]], Petersham *[[Sudbrook Park, Petersham]] *[[Ham Common, London|Ham Common]] *[[Kingston railway station (London)|Kingston railway station]] *[[Kingston Museum]] *[[Cesar Picton|Picton House]] *[[St Raphael's Church, Surbiton]] *[[Seething Wells|Seething Wells old waterworks]] *[[Giggs Hill Green]] *[[Scilly Isles, Surrey|Scilly Isles roundabout]] *[[Sandown Park Racecourse]] *Bridge over [[A3 road|A3]] at Cobham *[[Cobham RFC|Cobham RFC ground]] *Cobham Hospital ==History and events== The A307 follows the old route of the Portsmouth Road, particularly the section south of the junction with the [[A308 road|A308]]. Since two major projects of the 1930s and 1960s respectively the Portsmouth Road, the [[A3 road|A3 (Portsmouth Road)]] of today, has been diverted away from towns/villages instead through [[buffer zone|buffer land]] {{convert|1|mi}} or more from urban centres and is a tripled or dualled (duplicated as described at the time) in each direction. [[Robert Clive]] ("Clive of India") diverted it slightly believing it ran too close to his house at [[Claremont (country house)|Claremont]], the Landscape Garden of which remains and which it still borders. A [[watchmen (law enforcers)|watchman's]] box that also served as a [[village lock-up]], dating from 1787 is next to the 'Fox & Duck' in Petersham.{{cite web |url=https://sites.google.com/a/hamandpetersham.com/www/thehamlock-up |title=The Petersham Lock-Up |publisher=Ham and Petersham Association|accessdate=1 October 2012}} Responsibility for the north section, Kew Road and Richmond Road, passed from the crown to the [[Crown Commissioner|Commissioner of Works]] under the [[Crown Lands Act 1851]]. ===In living memory=== The A307 was closed during 1979 and 1980 for a total of almost 18 months by the repeated collapse of a [[Sewerage|sewer]] and fresh water culvert in the road's narrowest section which is in Petersham, an ordeal referred to as the [[Petersham Hole]]. The route has sometimes been used from a few hundred metres south of the Richmond Gate of [[Richmond Park]] to Kingston as part of the [[London-Surrey cycle classic]] events routes, depending on the availability of Park Road, Kingston which avoids the hairpin and sharper descent at Richmond Gate. ==References== {{reflist}} {{commons category|A307 road (England)|position=left}} {{GeoGroupTemplate}} {{GB A road zone 3}} {{coord|51.3972|-0.3108|dim:20000_region:GB|display=title|name=A307 road}} {{DEFAULTSORT:3-0307}} [[Category:Roads in London]] [[Category:Roads in Surrey]] [[Category:Transport in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames]] [[Category:Streets in the London Borough of Richmond upon Thames]]

{{Refimprove science|date=October 2018}} {{Other uses of|AUFS|aufs}} '''Absorbance Units Full Scale''' ('''AUFS''') is a ubiquitous unit of [[UV]] absorbance intensity.
==Usage==
AUFS is an arbitrary but ubiquitous unit of [[UV]] absorbance intensity.<ref name="Cshop1"/><ref name="LCE-def"/><ref name="LCE-start"/> It can be used in chemical analysis to quantify components in a mixture, as each components' [[Integral|integrated peak area]] correspond to their relative abundance.
==Application areas== * [[Analytical chemistry]] * [[Chromatography]]
==See also==
* [[Spectroscopy]]
==References== {{Reflist|2|refs=
<ref name="LCE-start">{{cite web|url=http://www.lcresources.com/resources/getstart/2e01.htm|title=Getting Started in HPLC - Section 2E. HPLC Detectors |dead-url=no|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180323044753/http://www.lcresources.com/resources/getstart/2e01.htm|archive-date=23 March 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref>

The Language of HPLC: A|id=AUFS |dead-url=no|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171212124929/http://www.lcresources.com/resources/getstart/a.htm|archive-date=12 December 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
}} <!-- https://www.chromforum.org/viewtopic.php?t=18722 -->

'''Advanced Gemini''' is a number of proposals that would have extended the [[Project Gemini|Gemini]] program by the addition of various missions, including [[human spaceflight|manned]] [[low Earth orbit]], [[circumlunar]] and [[moon landing|lunar landing]] missions. Gemini was the second manned spaceflight program operated by [[NASA]], and consisted of a two-seat spacecraft capable of maneuvering in orbit, docking with unmanned spacecraft such as [[Agena Target Vehicle]]s, and allowing the crew to perform tethered [[Extra-vehicular activity|extra-vehicular activities]].
A range of applications were considered for Advanced Gemini missions, including military flights, [[space station]] crew and logistics delivery, and lunar flights. The Lunar proposals ranged from reusing the docking systems developed for the [[Agena target vehicle]] on more powerful upper stages such as the [[Centaur (rocket stage)|Centaur]], which could propel the spacecraft to the [[Moon]], to complete modifications of the Gemini to enable it to land on the Lunar surface. Its applications would have ranged from manned lunar flybys before [[Apollo program|Apollo]] was ready, to providing emergency shelters or rescue for stranded Apollo crews, or even replacing the Apollo program.
Some of the Advanced Gemini proposals used "off-the-shelf" Gemini spacecraft, unmodified from the original program, while others featured modifications to allow the spacecraft to carry more crew, dock with space stations, visit the Moon, and perform other mission objectives. Other modifications considered included the addition of wings or a [[parasail]] to the spacecraft, in order to enable it to make a horizontal landing.
==Background== {{main|Project Gemini}} [[File:Gemini 6 7.jpg|right|thumb|200px|[[Gemini 7]] in orbit|alt=A black and white spacecraft, with the Earth below it.]] Gemini was the second American manned orbital spaceflight program, after [[Project Mercury|Mercury]]. It was intended to demonstrate technologies and techniques required for the [[Apollo program]], such as [[Extra-vehicular activity|extra-vehicular activities]], [[space rendezvous|rendezvous]] and docking, maneuvering in orbit and long duration flight.<ref name="Titans">{{cite book|last=Hacker|first=Barton C.|author2=Grimwood, James M.|title=On The Shoulders of Titans|publisher=NASA History Office|year=1977|series=NASA History Series|url=https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/19780012208_1978012208.pdf|accessdate=2009-07-08}}</ref>
The [[Gemini spacecraft]], which was built by [[McDonnell Aircraft]], was derived from the earlier [[Mercury spacecraft]], but modified to accommodate two [[astronaut]]s.<ref name="Titans"/> It was also equipped with a larger equipment module, allowing it to support longer missions, and maneuver in orbit. It was launched by the [[Titan II GLV|Titan II]] rocket flying from [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Launch Complex 19|Launch Complex 19]] at the [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station]].<ref name="GFL">{{cite book|last=Powell|first=Joel W.|author2=LeBrun, Art|title=Go For Launch: An Illustrated History of Cape Canaveral|publisher=Apogee Books|location=Canada|year=2006|isbn=1-894959-43-4|pages=218–222}}</ref> In total, twelve missions were launched, ten of which were manned. Following two unmanned test flights, the first manned flight, [[Gemini 3]], was launched on 23 March 1965. The program concluded on 15 November 1966, with the successful recovery of [[Gemini 12]].<ref name="Titans"/>
Many other applications were envisaged for the Gemini spacecraft at various stages before, during, and after the two years in which it was used by NASA for manned spaceflight.<ref name="PPDP">{{cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/data/6264gmcc.pdf|title=Preliminary Project Development Plan for an Advanced Manned Space Program Utilizing the Mark II Two Man Spacecraft|last=Space Task Group|date=1961-08-14|publisher=NASA|work=Encyclopedia Astronautica|accessdate=2009-07-02}}</ref><ref name="EA-GFamily">{{cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/craftfam/gemini.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080822151630/http://astronautix.com/craftfam/gemini.htm|archivedate=2008-08-22|title=Gemini |last=Wade|first=Mark|work=Encyclopedia Astronautica|accessdate=2009-07-08}}</ref> Although none of these proposals ever made it into operation, many were considered seriously, and in some cases flight hardware was constructed prior to cancellation. In the case of the [[Manned Orbital Laboratory]], a Gemini spacecraft was launched on a suborbital demonstration flight in support of the program.<ref name="EA-G"/> In some cases technology developed in the Advanced Gemini program has been reintegrated into other programs, such as components from the [[Titan III|Titan IIIM]], which was to have launched MOL, being used to upgrade other Titan rockets.<ref name="EA-Titan">{{cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/t/titan.html|title=Titan|last=Wade|first=Mark|work=Encyclopedia Astronautica|accessdate=2009-07-08}}</ref>
==Military applications== {{main|Blue Gemini|Manned Orbital Development System|Manned Orbital Laboratory<!--|Gemini B-->}} [[File:Gemini-B 1.jpg|right|225px|thumb|The Gemini B spacecraft|alt=A spacecraft in a museum, displaying a United States Air Force color scheme]] The [[United States Air Force]] intended to use the Gemini spacecraft to transport astronauts to its proposed [[space stations]], the [[Manned Orbital Development System]] and later the [[Manned Orbital Laboratory]] (MOL).<ref name="EA-G">{{cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/craft/gemini.htm|title=Gemini|last=Wade|first=Mark|work=Encyclopedia Astronautica|accessdate=2009-07-08|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090426032520/http://www.astronautix.com/craft/gemini.htm|archivedate=2009-04-26|df=}}</ref> These stations would have been launched by [[Titan IIIM]] rockets, with a Gemini spacecraft atop, eliminating the need for rendezvous and docking maneuvers. For this purpose, several modifications were made to the Gemini capsule, including the installation of a hatch in the [[heat shield]] to allow access to the space station.<ref name="EA-G"/>
[[File:MOL Launch.jpg|left|thumb|100px|Launch of Gemini B and OPS 0855|alt=A rocket launching]] In order to give its astronauts experience before these programs started, the [[Blue Gemini]] program was proposed, which would have seen USAF astronauts fly on NASA missions in order to practice various techniques required for their own missions.<ref name="Titans"/> This would have first seen cooperative missions between NASA and the US Air Force, with two missions flying with crews composed of one astronaut from NASA, and one from the USAF, followed by two missions with all-USAF crews, but performing missions for NASA. After these flights, the US Air Force would have flown a number of missions of its own. Firstly, it would have flown a two-man [[Agena target vehicle|Agena]] rendezvous and docking mission, followed by two one-man scientific or technology research missions.<ref name="TSR">{{cite web|url=http://www.thespacereview.com/article/582/1|title=The Blue Gemini blues|last=Day|first=Dwayne A.|date=2006-03-20|publisher=The Space Review|accessdate=2009-07-07}}</ref> Other proposed missions included tests of the [[Astronaut Mobility Unit]] which was designed to assist with EVAs, inertial navigation systems, and flying a [[radar imaging]] system.<ref name="TSR" />
[[File:MOL USAF.png|right|thumb|225px|Gemini separating from MOL in orbit|alt=Artist's impression of two spacecraft separating from each other, backdropped against the Earth]] MOL Launches would have been conducted from [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Space Launch Complex 40|Launch Complex 40]] at the [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station]], and [[Vandenberg AFB Space Launch Complex 6|Space Launch Complex 6]] at [[Vandenberg Air Force Base]]. In 1966, a test flight was launched from LC-40, using a [[Titan IIIC]]. It consisted of the [[Gemini B]] spacecraft, built from the spacecraft used for the [[Gemini 2]] test flight, atop [[OPS 0855]], a [[Boilerplate (spaceflight)|boilerplate]] MOL space station. Gemini B was released on a suborbital trajectory, and descended to Earth to test modifications made to the heat shield, and ensure that the access hatch would not affect its performance. OPS 0855 continued on to orbit. Early MOL stations would have only been manned by a single crew, launched with the station. Later stations would have been designed to be resupplied, and support multiple crews, delivered by additional Gemini spacecraft, or derivatives.
The MOL program was cancelled on 10 June 1969, in favor of unmanned reconnaissance satellites.<ref name="EA-MOL">{{cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/craft/mol.htm|title=MOL|last=Wade|first=Mark|work=Encyclopedia Astronautica|accessdate=2009-07-08|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090721035424/http://www.astronautix.com/craft/mol.htm|archivedate=2009-07-21|df=}}</ref> Some systems developed for the program were later used on unmanned missions, while the [[space suit]]s which were under development were transferred to NASA.<ref name="EA-MOL"/> The Titan IIIM rocket which was to launch MOL never flew, however some of the upgrades that were built into it were later used to upgrade other [[Titan (rocket family)|Titan]] rockets — the stretched first and second stages became the [[Titan III|Titan 34]], which was used as the core of some later [[Titan IIIB]] flights, and on the [[Titan 34D]]. The seven-segment [[solid rocket booster]]s were later introduced on the [[Titan IV]]A.<ref name="EA-Titan"/>
==Gemini Ferry== Several Gemini Ferry spacecraft were proposed to provide transportation of crews and cargo to NASA and USAF space stations in low Earth orbit. NASA contracted McDonnell to conduct a study into what modifications would be needed to allow the Gemini spacecraft to support this. Three spacecraft were envisioned; a manned spacecraft to transport crew to the stations, a manned spacecraft with a cargo module for both crew and cargo delivery, and a dedicated unmanned spacecraft to resupply the station every three or four months.<ref name="MORL"/>
The studies looked at minimizing required modifications to the Gemini spacecraft. Three docking methods were considered. The first was use of the existing docking system used on Gemini-Agena missions. This would have allowed the mission to be accomplished with little modification to the Gemini spacecraft needed, however crew transfer could only have been accomplished by means of an [[Extra-vehicular activity]] (EVA).<ref name="MORL">{{cite web|url=https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/19750069218_1975069218.pdf|title=Gemini Spacecraft Study for MORL Ferry Missions|date=1963-11-13|work=NASA Technical Reports Server|publisher=McDonnell Aircraft Corporation|accessdate=2009-07-08}}</ref> Changes that would have been required included strengthening the nose, installing two solid rockets to be used for a separation burn, adding the necessary equipment to perform the transfer EVA, and providing provisions for flight to and from the station. The number of retro-rockets would have been increased from four to six.<ref name="MORL"/> A second method would have seen the spacecraft dock in the same way, but after docking, the spacecraft would be swung round and attached to the side of the space station. A tunnel would then have been placed over the Gemini's hatches, allowing the crew to transfer to the station without performing an EVA. Some modifications to the hatches would have been required.<ref name="MORL" /> The final proposed docking method was to use a port mounted on the rear of the equipment module, which would have allowed the crew to transfer directly between the spacecraft and space station, through the docking port.<ref name="MORL"/>
A modified version of the spacecraft was proposed, which would have included a cargo module attached to the back of a modified equipment module.<ref name="EA-GF">{{cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/craft/gemferry.htm|title=Gemini Ferry|last=Wade|first=Mark|work=Encyclopedia Astronautica|accessdate=2009-07-08}}</ref> The spacecraft would have approached the station, and docked backwards using a port on the rear of the cargo module. If one of the forward docking configurations had been used for the Gemini itself, the docking would have been controlled remotely from the station, with the Gemini then separating from the cargo module and flying around the station to dock normally on a different port.<ref name="MORL"/> The rear-docking Gemini would have simply remained attached to the cargo module, with the crew boarding the station through it. Its docking would have been controlled by its own crew, from a station at the back of the cargo module.<ref name="MORL"/>
Two Gemini-derived spacecraft were considered for unmanned resupply flights. The first of these would have involved a Gemini spacecraft, with all systems for manned flight, re-entry and landing removed. The spacecraft would have docked using a port at the front of the spacecraft. Cargo would have been transferred through the nose of the spacecraft, where the re-entry attitude control system was located on the manned spacecraft.<ref name="MORL"/> The spacecraft was equipped with a liquid propellant engine to perform rendezvous, and to reboost the space station.<ref name="MORL"/> The other proposal was for a new spacecraft to be built for unmanned missions, but re-using as many Gemini systems as possible. It would have had a higher cargo capacity than the stripped-down version of the Gemini spacecraft.<ref name="MORL"/>
Crew-only or cargo-only supply missions would have been launched aboard a Titan II, and the [[Saturn I]] or [[Saturn IB]] would have been used for the combined crew and cargo spacecraft. Because of the increased power of the Saturn I, the Gemini spacecraft's [[ejection seat]]s would not have been able to propel the crew far enough in the event of an explosion, so a [[Launch escape system|launch escape tower]] was proposed, based on the one used on the [[Mercury spacecraft]].<ref name="MORL" /> The Titan IIIM was also considered to launch the heavier spacecraft.<ref name="EA-GF"/>
==Big Gemini== {{main|Big Gemini}} [[File:Big Gemini.png|right|200px|thumb|Big Gemini (Titan IIIG version)|alt=Drawing of a spacecraft which consists of a descent module, and a large cylindrical module behind it]] [[Big Gemini]], or Big G, grew out of a 1963 proposal called Gemini Transport, to develop an enlarged Gemini spacecraft with docking capability, which would take advantage of the increased capacity offered by the Saturn IB and Titan IIIM rockets.<ref name="EA-Trans">{{cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/craft/gemsport.htm|title=Gemini Transport|last=Wade|first=Mark|work=Encyclopedia Astronautica|accessdate=2009-07-08| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090607025753/http://www.astronautix.com/craft/gemsport.htm| archivedate= 7 June 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> It was designed to transport between nine and twelve astronauts into space, and to be able to dock with space stations, in support of [[Apollo Applications Program|Apollo Applications]] and MOL missions. It would have been launched by a [[Heavy lift launch vehicle]]; either a [[Titan III|Titan IIIG]] or [[Saturn INT-20]], the former being intended for use on US Air Force missions and the latter being intended for NASA missions. The Titan IIIM was also considered, which would have launched a smaller version of the spacecraft due to its lower capacity, to resupply MOL space stations later in the program. NASA also proposed several Saturn IB derivatives with solid first stages as alternatives to the INT-20, offering similar payload capacity.<ref name="EA-Big">{{cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/craft/bigemini.htm|title=Big Gemini|last=Wade|first=Mark|work=Encyclopedia Astronautica|accessdate=2009-07-07|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090611001322/http://www.astronautix.com/craft/bigemini.htm|archivedate=11 June 2009|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref>
The shape and mass of the spacecraft would have varied depending on the rocket that was to launch it. The Saturn-launched version had a short, conical cargo module, and a total mass of {{convert|47300|kg}} whereas the Titan IIIG-launched version featured a longer, cylindrical module, with a total mass of {{convert|59000|kg}}.<ref name="EA-Big"/> The Titan IIIM version would have been much shorter and lighter, with a mass of {{convert|15600|kg}}, as that rocket had less payload capacity than the Titan IIIG or Saturn.<ref name="EA-Big"/> The IIIG variant would have carried twelve crew, while the others had a maximum capacity of nine. Use of the NASA variant with the Apollo Service Module was also considered.<ref name="EA-Big"/>
Once in orbit, Big G would have docked with space stations using an Apollo docking probe mounted on the rear of the cargo module, which was in turn mounted on the rear of the re-entry module. The re-entry module itself would have been enlarged to accommodate the larger crew, and the modifications made to the spacecraft for the MOL program would have been incorporated, including the hatch in the heat shield, which would have been used to provide access to the cargo module. In the event of a launch failure, the [[launch escape system]] developed for the Apollo spacecraft would have been used to propel the re-entry module clear of the rocket.
Big G would have made landings on land, using a [[parasail]] or [[paraglider]] to guide it onto a runway or dry lake, such as the one at [[Edwards Air Force Base]]. It would have landed using skids derived from the [[North American X-15]].<ref name="EA-Big"/>
==Lunar exploration==
===Circumlunar missions=== [[File:GeminiCentaur.svg|right|thumb|330px|The Gemini-Centaur proposal for circumlunar missions|alt=Drawing of a spacecraft and a rocket stage docked together]] A number of studies investigated sending a Gemini spacecraft onto a circumlunar trajectory. Many of the proposals made for this involved a double-launch architecture, with the Gemini spacecraft rendezvousing with an upper stage in orbit. Upper stages that were considered included the [[Transtage]], the second stage of a Titan II, four different types of [[Centaur (rocket stage)|Centaur]], including the S-V variant developed for the Saturn I, the [[RM-81 Agena|Agena-D]], an enlarged Agena, and two Agenas burning in parallel.<ref name="Hammersmith">{{cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/data/gemlu64b.pdf|title=Advanced Gemini, Circumlunar Mission|last=Hammersmith|first=John L.|date=1964-04-03|publisher=NASA|work=Encyclopedia Astronautica|accessdate=2009-07-02}}</ref> Either a [[Titan (rocket family)|Titan]] or Saturn IB would have been used to launch the upper stage, while the Gemini would launch on the Titan II, as it had in the Gemini program.
Other proposals involved launching the Gemini spacecraft on a Titan IIIC, and refueling in low Earth orbit before proceeding to the Moon,<ref name="Hammersmith"/> and a single launch architecture using a three-stage variant of the Saturn IB.<ref name="Hammersmith"/>
The Gemini-Centaur proposal was predicted to have been able to achieve a 72-hour circumlunar flight.<ref name="Hammersmith"/> The Centaur would have performed [[trans-lunar injection]], before separating from the Gemini spacecraft.
Some concerns were raised that the Gemini spacecraft's heat shield would not have been able to protect it during the higher speed [[ballistic reentry]] associated with the trajectory that would have been required. NASA proposed using a thicker heat shield and more insulation to protect the spacecraft. This and several other modifications made the spacecraft too heavy to be launched by the Titan II rocket which was used for the original twelve Gemini missions, so several [[solid rocket motor]]s would have been added to allow this additional mass to be flown.<ref name="Hammersmith"/>
=== Lunar orbit missions === The Gemini spacecraft would have rendezvoused with stacked Centaur and Agena upper stages in low Earth orbit.<ref name="AGMCS">{{cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/data/6407gmfo.pdf|title=Advanced Gemini Missions Conceptual Study|date=1964-07-30|publisher=NASA|work=Encyclopedia Astronautica|accessdate=2009-07-02}}</ref> The Centaur would have placed the Gemini and Agena onto a circumlunar trajectory, along which they would coast until they reached the Moon. The Agena would then have been used to perform Lunar orbit insertion. Following the completion of activities in Lunar orbit, the Agena would have been fired again for trans-Earth injection.<ref name="AGMCS"/>
This architecture would have used a Titan II to launch the Gemini spacecraft, with a Saturn IB launching the upper stages.<ref name="AGMCS"/>
=== Lunar landing === [[File:Gemini LOR lander.svg|thumb|One of the early proposals for a lightweight one-man lander|alt=Drawing of a small spacecraft]] Using the Gemini spacecraft for a manned Lunar landing was considered as early as the original [[Mercury Mark II]] proposal which led to the Gemini program.<ref name="EA-LOR">{{cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/craft/gemnilor.htm|title=Gemini LOR|last=Wade|first=Mark|work=Encyclopedia Astronautica|accessdate=2009-07-08}}</ref> The initial proposal was for a [[Lunar orbit rendezvous]] mission, using a Gemini spacecraft and a lightweight, open cockpit lander, launched by a [[Saturn C-3]] rocket. It was the first time that Lunar orbit rendezvous was proposed as part of a lunar landing concept.<ref name="EA-LOR"/> The spacecraft would have been tested in Low Earth orbit before the Lunar missions, using two Titan II launches. The lander, which was designed by NASA's [[Langley Research Center]], would have had a mass of no more than {{convert|4372|kg}}. Some of the proposals had a mass as low as {{convert|1460|kg}}, with [[cryogenic propellant]]s being used in place of heavier [[hypergolic propellant]].<ref name="EA-LOR"/> The proposal was intended to provide a faster and lower-cost alternative to the Apollo program, which was at that time proposing a [[direct ascent]] landing.<ref name="EA-LOR"/>
Another proposal would have used a [[Saturn V]] to achieve a direct ascent mission profile.<ref name="EA-LL">{{cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/craft/gemander.htm|title=Gemini Lunar Lander|last=Wade|first=Mark|work=Encyclopedia Astronautica|accessdate=2009-07-08| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090605164346/http://www.astronautix.com/craft/gemander.htm| archivedate= 5 June 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The spacecraft consisted of four modules. The Retrograde Module would have been powered by an [[RL10]] engine, and used to propel the spacecraft during the trans-lunar coast. During landing, it would be used for the initial phases of powered descent. At an altitude of {{convert|1800|m}} above the Lunar surface, the RM would have been jettisoned, and a second module, the Terminal Landing Module, would have performed the final descent.<ref name="EA-LL"/> After landing, the spacecraft would have stayed on the Moon for a day, before it was propelled back to Earth. Launch from the Lunar Surface and trans-Earth injection would have been performed by the Service Module, which would also have contained components of the life support system, and other systems which were located in the Equipment Module of the Earth orbit Gemini spacecraft. The Reentry Module was based on the Gemini capsule, but would have been modified to allow it to reenter the atmosphere at the higher velocity that would have been required by a Lunar flight.<ref name="EA-LL"/> It was seen as the last effort by NASA managers and engineers who still advocated the direct ascent mission profile, and was intended to be cheaper, faster and safer than the Apollo lunar orbit rendezvous technique.<ref name="EA-LL"/>
=== Apollo rescue === {{see also|Apollo program}} Due to the risks associated with the Lunar landing, a number of rescue spacecraft were proposed, to be used to allow the crew of an Apollo mission to return to Earth safely in the event of a problem. Many of these designs were based around the Gemini spacecraft.<ref name="EA-LSRS">{{cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/craft/gemcraft.htm|title=Gemini Lunar Surface Rescue Spacecraft|last=Wade|first=Mark|work=Encyclopedia Astronautica|accessdate=2009-07-08}}</ref>
One of these proposals was the Gemini Lunar Orbit Rescue Vehicle, which was designed to retrieve the crew of an Apollo spacecraft stranded in orbit around the Moon. It was to have used a stretched reentry module to accommodate the three astronauts who would have been aboard the Apollo.<ref name="EA-LORV">{{cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/craft/gemilorv.htm|title=Gemini LORV|last=Wade|first=Mark|work=Encyclopedia Astronautica|accessdate=2009-07-08}}</ref> This would have been attached to a modified Equipment Module. The Equipment Module contained engines which would be used for Lunar orbit insertion and trans-Earth injection, as well as life support equipment to keep the crew alive until they returned to Earth.<ref name="EA-LORV"/> Launch and trans-Lunar injection would have been performed by a Saturn V. Once the spacecraft was in Lunar orbit, the Apollo crew would have boarded it by means of an EVA.<ref name="EA-LORV"/>
Another proposed spacecraft, the Gemini Lunar Surface Survival Shelter, was designed to be sent to the Moon ahead of an Apollo mission. It would have landed close to the planned [[Apollo landing site]], and if the Apollo Lunar Module's ascent stage failed to ignite, the crew would have performed an EVA to transfer to the LSSS.<ref name="EA-LSSS">{{cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/craft/gemelter.htm|title=Gemini Lunar Surface Survival Shelter|last=Wade|first=Mark|work=Encyclopedia Astronautica|accessdate=2009-07-08}}</ref> The shelter was not designed to take off again after landing, so an LSRS or another Apollo mission would then be sent to collect the crew, while the Command Module Pilot of the original Apollo mission would have returned to Earth alone aboard his spacecraft.<ref name="EA-LSSS"/> It consisted of a Gemini Reentry Module, which would have housed the astronauts while they awaited rescue, and a descent stage containing life support systems, consumables, and the engine and propellant used to land the spacecraft.<ref name="EA-LSSS"/>
The Gemini Lunar Surface Rescue Spacecraft was intended to fly a direct ascent mission, launched by a Saturn V. Descent stages, built from either the descent stage of the [[Apollo Lunar Module]], or from the [[Apollo Service Module]], would have reduced the spacecraft's velocity as it approached the Moon. One configuration used two Service Modules and one LEM descent stage, with the LEM descent stage performing the final landing, and then being reused for ascent from the Lunar surface and trans-Earth injection.<ref name="EA-LSRS"/> The other configuration used three LEM descent stages, with the second being used for landing and the third for ascent and TEI.<ref name="EA-LSRS"/> The LSRS would have landed close to the Apollo Lunar Module on the Moon, and the Apollo crew would have transferred to it by EVA.<ref name="EA-LSRS"/>
Following the [[Apollo 1]] fire in January 1967, NASA conducted a safety review of the Apollo program. In response to this review, McDonnell proposed the Universal Lunar Rescue Vehicle, a repackaged version of the Lunar Surface Rescue Spacecraft with an enlarged capsule to make room for the three astronauts who were being rescued. It was intended to rescue an Apollo crew at almost any point while they were at the Moon, should an anomaly occur.<ref name="EA-LSRS"/> Some ULRV designs included five seats, with two astronauts piloting it to the Moon.<ref name="EA-LSRS"/> The proposal was considered, but rejected due to lack of funds.<ref name="EA-LSRS"/>
==Other proposals== A number of other applications were considered for the Gemini spacecraft.
===Manned Orbital Telescope=== The Manned Orbital Telescope was a proposal for a manned spacecraft for [[astronomy|astronomical]] or [[Sun|solar]] observation.<ref name="Telescope">{{cite web|url=https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/19660017399_1966017399.pdf|title=A System Study of a Manned Orbital Telescope|date=October 1965|work=NASA Technical Reports Server|publisher=Boeing|accessdate=2009-07-07}}</ref> It would have used the larger reentry module which was also proposed for the Big Gemini spacecraft, and would have been launched on a Saturn IB.<ref name="EA-GO">{{cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/craft/gematory.htm|title=Gemini Observatory|last=Wade|first=Mark|work=Encyclopedia Astronautica|accessdate=2009-07-07| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090607030010/http://www.astronautix.com/craft/gematory.htm| archivedate= 7 June 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The enlarged reentry module was also considered for a spacecraft proposed at the same time, which would have been used to rescue the crews of manned spacecraft that were stranded in low Earth orbit. It would have launched atop a Titan IIIC, once in orbit it would have maneuvered by means of a Transtage integrated into the equipment module. The larger capsule would have been used to accommodate the crew of the spacecraft which required rescuing.<ref name="EA-RG">{{cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/craft/resemini.htm|title=Rescue Gemini|last=Wade|first=Mark|work=Encyclopedia Astronautica|accessdate=2009-07-07| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090607025819/http://www.astronautix.com/craft/resemini.htm| archivedate= 7 June 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
===Rendezvous with a Pegasus satellite=== Another proposed mission would have seen a Gemini spacecraft rendezvous with a [[Pegasus (satellite)|Pegasus]] satellite in low Earth orbit. The spacecraft would have either been launched directly into an orbit to rendezvous with the Pegasus, or into a lower orbit, subsequently docking with an Agena, and using that to raise its orbit. The Gemini would have flown around the Pegasus, and then one of the crew would have performed an EVA to recover a piece of one of the spacecraft's micrometeoroid detection panels.<ref name="EA-Intercept">{{cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/craft/gemector.htm|title=Gemini Satellite Inspector|last=Wade|first=Mark|work=Encyclopedia Astronautica|accessdate=2009-07-07| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090607030018/http://www.astronautix.com/craft/gemector.htm| archivedate= 7 June 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> This mission would have been used to prove that rendezvous could be accomplished with any spacecraft, to collect data on the satellite's exposure to micrometeoroids — supporting data that the satellite had returned itself, and to demonstrate technology for military flights to inspect hostile satellites.<ref name="EA-Intercept"/>
===Gemini Paraglider=== [[File:Gemini paraglider.JPG|right|thumb|alt=A spacecraft on wheels, suspended from a large triangular wing, in flight close to the ground.|Gemini [[paraglider]]]] Several missions were proposed to demonstrate methods of landing the Gemini spacecraft on land. The spacecraft had originally been designed to land using a flexible [[Rogallo wing]] and a set of skis or wheels,<ref name="ParagliderReport">{{cite web|url=https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/19680072651_1968072651.pdf|title=Paraglider Landing System Test Program Final Report|date=December 1965|work=NASA Technical Reports Server|publisher=North American Aviation|accessdate=2009-07-08}}</ref> however this was abandoned in favor of [[Splashdown (spacecraft landing)|splashdown]]s under parachutes due to delays in development and failures during testing.<ref name="ParagliderWane">{{cite book|last=Hacker|first=Barton C.|author2=Grimwood, James M.|title=On The Shoulders of Titans|publisher=NASA History Office|year=1977|edition=Online|series=NASA History Series|chapter=Paraglider on the Wane|url=http://www.hq.nasa.gov/office/pao/History/SP-4203/ch7-3.htm|accessdate=2009-07-07}}</ref><ref name="ParagliderCancelled">{{cite book|last=Hacker|first=Barton C.|author2=Grimwood, James M.|title=On The Shoulders of Titans|publisher=NASA History Office|year=1977|edition=Online|series=NASA History Series|chapter=Titan II Makes the Grade, But Not Paraglider|url=http://www.hq.nasa.gov/office/pao/History/SP-4203/ch8-2.htm|accessdate=2009-07-07}}</ref> As the proposed Big Gemini spacecraft would have landed this way, McDonnell Aircraft asked NASA to consider flying standard Gemini spacecraft with the paraglider in order to test the system before it would be required operationally.<ref name="EA-GP">{{cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/craft/gemlider.htm|title=Gemini Paraglider|last=Wade|first=Mark|work=Encyclopedia Astronautica|accessdate=2009-07-07| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090607025747/http://www.astronautix.com/craft/gemlider.htm| archivedate= 7 June 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
===Winged Gemini=== Another alternative landing concept was the US Air Force's proposal to attach wings to the spacecraft.<ref name="EA-WG">{{cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/craft/winemini.htm|title=Winged Gemini|last=Wade|first=Mark|work=Encyclopedia Astronautica|accessdate=2009-07-07|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090607025824/http://www.astronautix.com/craft/winemini.htm|archivedate=7 June 2009|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref> This proposal arose soon after the cancellation of the [[X-20 Dyna-Soar]], and would have seen a Gemini spacecraft attached to a set of wings developed during the [[ASSET (spaceplane)|ASSET]] program.<ref name="EA-WG"/> This would have been launched by a Titan II rocket, and would have been unable to maneuver in orbit. Another proposal saw the spacecraft being launched by a [[Titan IIIA]] or IIIC, using the Transtage for maneuvering. Once the mission was complete, the spacecraft would have been deorbited by means of five [[solid rocket motor]]s.<ref name="EA-WG"/>
===Long-duration missions=== There were also proposals to use the Gemini spacecraft to conduct long-duration missions to small, purpose-built space stations in low-Earth orbit. One proposal saw a space station based on the Agena, which would have been used to provide propulsion and attitude control for the station. A pressurized module between the Agena and the docking adapter would have been used by the crew for accommodation and to conduct experiments. The crew would have boarded the Agena by means of an inflatable tunnel between the hatches and its airlock.<ref name="EA-ED">{{cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/craft/extemini.htm|title=Extended Mission Gemini|last=Wade|first=Mark|work=Encyclopedia Astronautica|accessdate=2009-07-08| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090607030000/http://www.astronautix.com/craft/extemini.htm| archivedate= 7 June 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The [[Pecan (spacecraft)|Pecan]] spacecraft was a similar proposal.<ref name="EA-GPN">{{cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/craft/gempecan.htm|title=Gemini Pecan|last=Wade|first=Mark|work=Encyclopedia Astronautica|accessdate=2009-07-08| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090607030029/http://www.astronautix.com/craft/gempecan.htm| archivedate= 7 June 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Apollo Applications Program]] *[[Apollo program]] *[[DIRECT]] *[[Project Gemini]] *[[Manned Orbital Laboratory]] *[[Skylab]] *[[Soyuz program]]

{{Italic title}} '''''An Elementary Treatise on Electricity''''' is a book by [[James Clerk Maxwell]]. The origin of the book are lecture notes Clerk Maxwell gave to members of the [[Cavendish Laboratory]], which he founded.
==External links== *[https://archive.org/details/elementarytreati00maxwrich ''An Elementary Treatise on Electricity'' (1881)] *[https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&id=ecUKAAAAIAAJ&dq=%22An+Elementary+Treatise+on+Electricity%22&printsec=frontcover&source=web&ots=poJb0Z9NIp&sig=-lnw5aBMSt57kzbNI7oPnWuGr7s ''An Elementary Treatise on Electricity'' (1888)]
