revision.text:
The '''law of specific nerve energies''', first proposed by [[Johannes Peter Müller]] in 1835, is that the nature of perception is defined by the pathway over which the sensory information is carried. Hence, the origin of the sensation is not important. Therefore, the difference in perception of seeing, hearing, and touch are not caused by differences in the stimuli themselves but by the different nervous structures that these stimuli excite. For example, pressing on the [[human eye|eye]] elicits sensations of flashes of [[light]] because the [[neuron]]s in the [[retina]] send a signal to the [[occipital lobe]]. Despite the sensory input's being mechanical, the experience is visual.
==Quotation==
Here is Müller's statement of the law, from ''Handbuch der Physiologie des Menschen für Vorlesungen'', 2nd Ed., translated by Edwin Clarke and Charles Donald O'Malley: ::''The same cause, such as electricity, can simultaneously affect all sensory organs, since they are all sensitive to it; and yet, every sensory nerve reacts to it differently; one nerve perceives it as light, another hears its sound, another one smells it; another tastes the electricity, and another one feels it as pain and shock. One nerve perceives a luminous picture through mechanical irritation, another one hears it as buzzing, another one senses it as pain. . . He who feels compelled to consider the consequences of these facts cannot but realize that the specific sensibility of nerves for certain impressions is not enough, since all nerves are sensitive to the same cause but react to the same cause in different ways. . . (S)ensation is not the conduction of a quality or state of external bodies to consciousness, but the conduction of a quality or state of our nerves to consciousness, excited by an external cause.''
==Clarification==
As the above quotation shows, Müller's law seems to differ from the modern statement of the law in one key way. Müller attributed the [[quale|quality]] of an experience to some specific quality of the energy in the nerves. For example, the visual experience from light shining into the eye, or from a poke in the eye, arises from some special quality of the energy carried by [[optic nerve]], and the auditory experience from sound coming into the ear, or from electrical stimulation of the [[cochlea]], arises from some different, special quality of the energy carried by the [[auditory nerve]]. In 1912, [[Lord Edgar Douglas Adrian]] showed that all neurons carry the same energy, electrical energy in the form of [[action potential]]s. That means that the quality of an experience depends on the part of the brain to which nerves deliver their action potentials (e.g., light from nerves arriving at the [[visual cortex]] and sound from nerves arriving at the [[auditory cortex]]).
In 1945, [[Roger Sperry]] showed that it is the location in the brain to which nerves attach that determines experience. He studied [[amphibian]]s whose optic nerves cross completely, so that the left eye connects to the right side of the brain and the right eye connects to the left side of the brain. He was able to cut the optic nerves and cause them to regrow on the opposite side of the brain so that the left eye now connected to the left side of the brain and the right eye connected to the right side of the brain. He then showed that these animals made the opposite movements from the ones they would have made before the operation. For example, before the operation, the animal would move to the left to get away from a large object approaching from the right. After the operation, the animal would move to the right in response to the same large object approaching from the right. Sperry showed similar results in other animals including [[mammal]]s ([[rat]]s), this work contributing to his [[Nobel Prize]] in 1981.
==References== #Norrsell U., Finger S. and Lajonchere C. (1999) Cutaneous sensory spots and the "law of specific nerve energies": history and development of ideas. ''Brain Research Bulletin, 48''(5): 457-465. #Sperry, R. W. (1945). Restoration of vision after crossing of optic nerves and after transplantation of eye. ''Journal of Neurophysiology, 8'', 15-28. #[[Jakob von Uexküll|Uexküll, Jakob von]] (1947). ''Der Sinn des Lebens: Gedanken über die Aufgaben der Biologie. (Mitgeteilt in einer Interpretation der zu Bonn 1824 gehaltenen Vorlesung des Johannes Müller 'Von dem Bedürfnis der Physiologie nach einer philosophischen Naturbetrachtung', mit einem Ausblick von Thure von Uexküll.)'' Godesberg: Verlag Helmut Küpper.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Law Of Specific Nerve Energies}} [[Category:Sensory systems]] [[Category:Biology theories]]

This is a '''list of [[Plan 9 from Bell Labs|Plan 9]] [[Computer program|program]]s'''. Many of these programs are very similar to the [[List of Unix programs|UNIX programs]] with the same name, other are to be found only on [[Plan 9 from Bell Labs|Plan 9]]. Others again share only the name, but have a different behaviour.
== [[System software]] ==
=== General user === * [[dd (Unix)|dd]]<ref>{{man|1|dd|Plan 9}}</ref> – convert and copy a file * [[date (unix)|date]]<ref>{{man|1|date|Plan 9}}</ref> – date and time * [[echo (command)|echo]]<ref>{{man|1|echo|Plan 9}}</ref> – print arguments * [[file (command)|file]]<ref>{{man|1|file|Plan 9}}</ref> – determine file type * [[ns (Plan 9)|ns]]<ref>{{man|1|ns|Plan 9}}</ref> – display namespace * [[plumber (Plan 9)|plumb]]<ref>{{man|1|plumb|Plan 9}}</ref> – send message to plumber * [[plumber (Plan 9)|plumber]]<ref>{{man|4|plumber|Plan 9}}</ref> – interprocess messaging * [[rc]]<ref>{{man|1|rc|Plan 9}}</ref> – rc is the Plan 9 shell * [[rio window manager|rio]]<ref>{{man|1|rio|Plan 9}}</ref> – the new Plan 9 windowing system * [[8½ (Plan 9)|8½]] – the old Plan 9 windowing system [http://plan9.bell-labs.com/sys/doc/8%C2%BD.html] * [[uptime]]<ref>{{man|1|uptime|Plan 9}}</ref> – show how long the system has been running
=== System management ===
==== [[Process (computing)|Processes]] and tasks management ==== * [[time (unix)|time]]<ref>{{man|1|time|Plan 9}}</ref> – time a command * [[kill (command)|kill]],<ref name="kill">{{man|1|kill|Plan 9}}</ref> [[slay (Plan9)|slay]],<ref name="kill"/> [[broke (Plan9)|broke]]<ref name="kill"/> – print commands to kill processes * [[sleep (command)|sleep]]<ref>{{man|1|sleep|Plan 9}}</ref> – suspend execution for an interval * [[ps (Unix)|ps]]<ref name="ps">{{man|1|ps|Plan 9}}</ref> – process status * [[ps (Unix)|psu]]<ref name="ps"/> – process status information about processes started by a specific user
==== User management and support ==== * [[passwd]],<ref name="passwd">{{man|1|passwd|Plan 9}}</ref> netkey,<ref name="passwd"/> iam – change user password * [[who (Unix)|who]]<ref>{{man|1|who|Plan 9}}</ref> – who is using the machine * [[man (Unix)|man]],<ref name="man">{{man|1|man|Plan 9}}</ref> lookman<ref name="man"/> – print or find pages of this manual
==== File system and server ==== * /boot/boot<ref>{{man|8|boot|Plan 9}}</ref> – connect to the root file server * fossil/[[fossil (file system)|fossil]], fossil/flchk, fossil/flfmt, fossil/conf, fossil/last – archival file server * history<ref>{{man|1|history|Plan 9}}</ref> – print file names from the dump * users<ref>{{man|6|users|Plan 9}}</ref> – file server user list format * vac<ref>{{man|1|vac|Plan 9}}</ref> – create a vac archive on Venti * venti/buildindex, venti/checkarenas, venti/checkindex, venti/conf, venti/copy,<ref name="venti" /> venti/fmtarenas, venti/fmtindex, venti/fmtisect, venti/rdarena, venti/rdarenablocks, venti/read,<ref name="venti">{{man|1|venti|Plan 9}}</ref> venti/wrarenablocks, venti/write<ref name="venti" /> – Venti maintenance and debugging commands * venti/[[venti]],<ref>{{man|8|venti|Plan 9}}</ref> venti/sync – an archival block storage server * yesterday,<ref name="yesterday">{{man|1|yesterday|Plan 9}}</ref> diffy<ref name="yesterday" /> – print file names from the dump
==== Hardware devices ==== * [[setrtc]] – set [[Real-time clock|real time clock]](RTC) on PC hardware
=== Files and text ===
==== Filesystem utilities ==== * [[chgrp]]<ref>{{man|1|chgrp|Plan 9}}</ref> – change file group * [[chmod]]<ref>{{man|1|chmod|Plan 9}}</ref> – change mode * [[cp (Unix)|cp]],<ref name="cp">{{man|1|cp|Plan 9}}</ref> fcp,<ref name="cp" /> [[mv]]<ref name="cp" /> – copy, move files * [[du (Unix)|du]]<ref>{{man|1|du|Plan 9}}</ref> – disk usage * [[ls]],<ref name="ls">{{man|1|ls|Plan 9}}</ref> lc<ref name="ls"/> – list contents of directory * [[mkdir]]<ref>{{man|1|mkdir|Plan 9}}</ref> – make a directory * bind,<ref name="bind">{{man|1|bind|Plan 9}}</ref> mount,<ref name="bind"/> umount<ref name="bind"/> – change name space * [[pwd]],<ref name="pwd">{{man|1|pwd|Plan 9}}</ref> pbd<ref name="pwd"/> – working directory * [[rm (Unix)|rm]]<ref>{{man|1|rm|Plan 9}}</ref> – remove files * [[touch (Unix)|touch]]<ref>{{man|1|touch|Plan 9}}</ref> – set modification date of a file
==== Archivers and compression ==== * [[ar (Unix)|ar]]<ref>{{man|1|ar|Plan 9}}</ref> – archive and library maintainer * [[gzip]],<ref name="gzip">{{man|1|gzip|Plan 9}}</ref> [[gunzip]],<ref name="gzip"/> [[bzip2]],<ref name="gzip"/> [[bunzip2]],<ref name="gzip"/> [[compress]],<ref name="gzip"/> [[uncompress]],<ref name="gzip"/> [[zip (file format)|zip]],<ref name="gzip"/> unzip<ref name="gzip"/> – compress and expand data * [[tar (file format)|tar]]<ref>{{man|1|tar|Plan 9}}</ref> – archiver
==== Text processing ==== * [[awk]] – pattern-directed scanning and processing language * [[cat (Unix)|cat]], read – catenate files * [[cmp (Unix)|cmp]] – compare two files * [[diff]] – differential file comparator * [[doc2txt]], [[xls2txt]] – extract printable strings from Microsoft Office documents * doctype – intuit command line for formatting a document * [[fmt (Unix)|fmt]], [[htmlfmt]] – simple text formatters * [[freq (Unix)|freq]] – print histogram of character frequencies * [[grep]] – search a file for a pattern * [[idiff]] – interactive diff * mc – multicolumn print * p<ref>{{man|1|p|Plan 9}}</ref> – paginate * pr<ref>{{man|1|pr|Plan 9}}</ref> – print file * [[sed]] – stream editor * spell, sprog – find spelling errors * [[split (Unix)|split]] – split a file into pieces * [[tail (Unix)|tail]] – deliver the last part of a file * [[tcs]] – translate character sets * [[tr (program)|tr]] – translate characters * [[wc (Unix)|wc]] – word count * xd – hex, octal, decimal or ASCII dump of file
==== Editors ==== * [[acme (text editor)|acme]]<ref>{{man|1|acme|Plan 9}}</ref> – interactive text editor and shell * [[ed (Unix)|ed]]<ref>{{man|1|ed|Plan 9}}</ref> – text editor * [[sam (program)|sam]]<ref>{{man|1|sam|Plan 9}}</ref> – screen editor with structural regular expressions
=== Communication, networking and remote access === * con, [[telnet]], rx, xms, xmr – remote login, execution, and XMODEM file transfer * cpu – connection to CPU server * dial/at, dial/drain, dial/expect, dial/pass – dialer scripting tools * [[netstat]] – summarize network connections * replica/changes, replica/pull, replica/push, replica/scan – client–server replica management * [[Secure Shell|ssh]], sshnet, [[secury copy|scp]], aux/sshserve – secure login and file copy from/to Unix or Plan 9 * tel, iwhois – look in phone book * vncs, vncv – remote frame buffer server and viewer for Virtual Network Computing (VNC)
==== Email and news programs ==== * faces, seemail, vwhois – mailbox interface * mail – mail and mailboxes * news – print news items * upas/[[filter (Unix)|filter]], upas/list, upas/deliver, upas/token, upas/vf – filtering mail * upas/fs – mail file server * upas/marshal – formatting and sending mail * upas/ml, upas/mlmgr, upas/mlowner – unmoderated mailing lists * upas/nedmail – reading mail * upas/scanmail, upas/testscan – spam filters * upas/send – mail routing and delivery * upas/smtp, upas/smtpd – mail transport
==== Network system services ==== * ip/[[dhcpd]], ip/dhcpleases, ip/rarpd, ip/tftpd – Internet booting * aux/listen – listen for calls on a network device * ndb/query, ndb/mkhash, ndb/mkdb, ndb/cs, ndb/csquery, ndb/dns, ndb/dnsquery, ndb/ipquery, ndb/dnsdebug, ndb/mkhosts – network database * upas/pop3, ip/imap4d – mail servers * aux/timesync – NTP client
==== Network utilities ==== * aan – always available network * ip/ipconfig, ip/rip – Internet configuration and routing * ip/telnetd, ip/rlogind, ip/rexexec, ip/ftpd – Internet remote access daemons * ip/[[Ping (networking utility)|ping]], ip/gping, ip/[[traceroute]], ip/hogports – probe the Internet * snoopy – spy on network packets * ip/udpecho – echo UDP packets
=== Security === * auth/aescbc, ipso, auth/[[secstore]] – secstore commands * auth/changeuser, auth/wrkey, auth/convkeys, auth/convkeys2, auth/printnetkey, auth/status, auth/authsrv, auth/guard.srv, auth/login, auth/disable, auth/enable – maintain authentication databases * auth/[[factotum (software)|factotum]], auth/fgui – authentication agent * auth/secstored, auth/secuser – secstore commands * [[delkey]] – delete keys from factotum
=== Programming tools ===
==== [[Compiler]]s and [[programming tools]] ==== * 0a, 1a, 2a, 5a, 7a, 8a, ka, qa, va – assemblers * 0c, 1c, 2c, 5c, 7c, 8c, kc, qc, vc – C compilers * 0l, 1l, 2l, 5l, 7l, 8l, kl, ql, vl – loaders * [[Acid (debugger)|acid]], truss, trump – debugger * [[bc (Unix)|bc]] – arbitrary–precision arithmetic language * cb – C program beautifier * [[C preprocessor|cpp]] – C language preprocessor * [[ktrace]] – interpret kernel stack dumps * [[Memory leak|leak]], [[kmem]] – help find memory leaks * [[mk (software)|mk]], [[membername]] – maintain (make) related files * [[Patch (Unix)|patch]] – simple patch creation and tracking system * [[Portable C Compiler|pcc]] – [[ANSI/POSIX Environment|APE]] C compiler driver * [[Strip (Unix)|strip]] – remove symbols from binary files * [[syscall]] – test a system call * [[yacc]] – yet another compiler-compiler
== [[Application software]] ==
=== [[Web browser]]s === * [[Abaco (web browser)|abaco]]<ref>{{man|1|abaco|Plan 9}}</ref> – a "lame" text-based and graphical web browser * i – rough web browser, based on [[charon (web browser)|charon]] * [[Links (web browser)|links]] – a text-based and graphical web browser * mothra – a very basic web browser
=== Desktop publishing === * deroff, delatex – remove formatting requests * [[eqn (software)|eqn]] – typeset mathematics * [[ghostscript|gs]] – Aladdin Ghostscript (PostScript and PDF language interpreter) * htmlroff – HTML formatting and typesetting * [[Lp (Unix)|lp]] – printer output * ms2html, html2ms – convert between troff's ms macros and html * page – view FAX, image, graphic PostScript PDF, and typesetter output files * pic, tpic – troff and tex preprocessors for drawing pictures * pr – print file * [[ps2pdf]], [[pdf2ps]] – convert between PostScript and PDF * [[tbl]] – format tables for nroff or troff * [[troff]], [[nroff]] – text formatting and typesetting * troff2html – convert troff output into HTML
=== Graphics and multimedia === * getmap,<ref name="colors">{{man|1|colors|Plan 9}}</ref> colors<ref name="colors"/> – display color map * jpg,<ref name="jpg">{{man|1|jpg|Plan 9}}</ref> gif,<ref name="jpg"/> png,<ref name="jpg"/> ppm,<ref name="jpg"/> bmp,<ref name="jpg"/> v210,<ref name="jpg"/> yuv,<ref name="jpg"/> ico,<ref name="jpg"/> togif,<ref name="jpg"/> toppm,<ref name="jpg"/> topng,<ref name="jpg"/> toico<ref name="jpg"/> – view and convert pictures
=== Various utilities and games === * astro<ref>{{man|7|astro|Plan 9}}</ref> – print astronomical information * [[cal (program)|cal]]<ref>{{man|1|cal|Plan 9}}</ref> – print calendar * calendar<ref>{{man|1|calendar|Plan 9}}</ref> – print upcoming events * clock<ref>{{man|1|date|Plan 9}}</ref> – draws a simple analog clock * dict<ref>{{man|7|dict|Plan 9}}</ref> – dictionary browser * [[fortune (program)|fortune]]<ref>{{man|1|fortune|Plan 9}}</ref> – sample lines from a file * juke,<ref name="juke">{{man|7|juke|Plan 9}}</ref> games/jukebox,<ref name="juke"/> games/jukefs<ref name="juke"/> – music jukebox * lens<ref>{{man|1|lens|Plan 9}}</ref> – interactive screen magnifier * map,<ref name="map">{{man|7|map|Plan 9}}</ref> mapdemo<ref name="map"/> – draw maps on various projections * games/playlistfs<ref>{{man|1|date|Plan 9}}</ref> – playlist file system * thesaurus<ref>{{man|7|playlistfs|Plan 9}}</ref> – search online thesaurus * scat<ref>{{man|7|scat|Plan 9}}</ref> – sky catalogue
==References== {{reflist|33em}}

page.title: List of aftershocks of April 2015 Nepal earthquake

revision.text:
[[File:2015 Nepal depremi (7).jpg|thumb|Houses destroyed by 2015 Nepal earthquake|300px]] [[File:2015 Nepal earthquake.svg|thumb|right|Aftershocks of 2015 Nepal earthquake|300px]] The following is a list of [[aftershock]]s that occurred after the [[April 2015 Nepal earthquake|earthquake in Nepal on 25 April 2015]]. There was some seismic activity in the [[Jumla District|Jumla district]] before the main shock.{{cite web|url=https://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/eventpage/us2000281p#general_summary|title=M5.0 - 51km SSE of Jumla, Nepal|work=usgs.gov}}{{cite web|url=https://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/eventpage/us20002a35#general_summary|title=M4.3 - 43km SSE of Jumla, Nepal|work=usgs.gov}} However, they are not [[foreshock]]s to the main shock. {{As of|2015|June|07}}, over 304 aftershocks have occurred.{{cite web|url=http://www.seismonepal.gov.np/|title=Aftershocks of Gorkha Earthquake|publisher=National Seismological Centre, Nepal}} The large number of aftershocks after the earthquake is considered normal by seismologists. According to seismologist Roger Musson, the standard pattern for aftershocks is that the biggest aftershock will be one day after, and one magnitude less. Thus, the 6.7 magnitude aftershock on 26 April 2015 following the 7.9 magnitude main shock would fit this pattern. It is highly unlikely that the earthquake was a foreshock preceding an even larger earthquake. Therefore, an earthquake larger than 7.9 in the near future after 25 April 2015 is not expected.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/nepal/11565700/Nepal-earthquake-How-dangerous-are-aftershocks.html|title=Nepal Earthquake: How Dangerous Are Aftershocks?|work=The Telegraph, UK}} ==List of aftershocks 5.0 and higher== The list below is incomplete and maybe inaccurate for some aftershocks. Note: The list below shows bigger earthquakes only. {| class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size: 100%; width:100%; text-align: center" ! class="unsortable" | # ! UTC timestamp ! Date ! Time{{efn|Times are Nepal Standard Time (NST): [[Universal Coordinated Time|UTC]] + 05:45.}} ! District ! {{M|mag}} ! Impact ! ISC #{{efn|[[International Seismological Centre]] event identifier.}} ! Ref. |- |Main |2015-04-25 06:11:19 |25 April || 11:56 |Gorkha |7.9 |9,061 deaths;
23,447 injured |{{eq-isc-link|-607208674}} |{{cite anss|Ghorka|25 April 11:56|us20002926|M7.8 — 34km ESE of Lamjung, Nepal}} |- |01 |2015-04-25 06:38:42 |25 April || 12:22 |[[Sindhupalchowk District|Sindhupalchowk]] |5.5 | |{{eq-isc-link|-607260063}} |{{cite anss|Kodari|25 April 12:22|us2000292w|M5.1 — 28km SSW of Kodari, Nepal}} |- |02 |2015-04-25 06:45:20 |25 April || 12:30 |Gorkha |6.6 | |{{eq-isc-link|-607260065}} |{{cite anss|Lamjung|25 April 12:30|us2000292y|M6.6 — 49km E of Lamjung, Nepal}} |- |03 |2015-04-25 06:56:34 |25 April || 12:41 |[[Rasuwa District|Rasuwa]] |5.7 | |{{eq-isc-link|-607260068}} |{{cite anss|Nakarkot|25 April 12:41|us20002934|M5.5 — 25km NNE of Nagarkot, Nepal}} |- |04 |2015-04-25 07:07:59 |25 April || 12:52 |Rasuwa |5.0 | |{{eq-isc-link|-607208681}} |{{cite anss|Kodari|25 April 12:52|us20002939|M5.0 — 25km S of Kodari, Nepal}} |- |05 |2015-04-25 07:47:02 |25 April || 13:32 |[[Tibet Autonomous Region|Tibet]] |5.1 | |{{eq-isc-link|-607208683}} | |- |06 |2015-04-25 08:16:59 |25 April || 14:02 |Sindhupalchowk |5.2 | |{{eq-isc-link|-607211764}} | |- |07 |2015-04-25 |25 April || 14:05 |Gorkha |5.1 | | | |- |08 |2015-04-25 |25 April || 14:14 |Gorkha |5.2 | | | |- |09 |2015-04-25 |25 April || 14:40 |[[Kavrepalanchowk District|Kavrepalanchowk]] |5.7 | | | |- |10 |2015-04-25 |25 April || 14:48 |Rasuwa |5.3 | | | |- |11 |2015-04-25 |25 April || 15:02 |Tibet |5.9 | | | |- |12 |2015-04-25 |25 April || 15:15 |Sindhupalchowk |5.5 | | | |- |12 |2015-04-25 |25 April || 18:29 |Gorkha |5.5 | | | |- |13 |2015-04-25 17:42:50 |25 April || 23:27 |Tibet |5.4 | | |{{cite anss|Chongdui|25 April 23:27|us2000297g|M5.4 — 22km WNW of Chongdui, China}} |- |14 |2015-05-12 07:05:19 |12 May || 12:50 |DolakhaThis event considered an aftershock of the April 25th event. |7.3 {{ref|datanote}} |218 died,
2500+ injured |{{eq-isc-link|-610588278}} | |- |15 |2015-05-12 |12 May || 13:20 |Dolakha |6.3 | | | |- |16 |2015-05-24 21:38:41 |25 May || 03:23 |Gorkha |5.0 | | | |- |17 |2015-05-26 |26 May || 22:52 |Rasuwa |5.0 | | | |- |18 |2015-05-29 |29 May || 15:44 |Dhading |5.2 | | | |- |19 |2015-06-11 |11 June || 21:57 |Sindhupalchowk |5.3 | | | |- |20 |2015-06-13 |13 June || 07:06 |Dolakha |5.2 | | | |- |21 |2015-06-17 |17 June || 06:14 |Sindhupalchowk |5.2 | | | |- |22 |2015-06-17 |17 June || 08:00 |Sindhupalchowk/Tibet |5.1 | | | |- |23 |2015-06-20 |20 June || 18:08 |[[Rukum District|Rukum]] |5.4 | | | |- |24 |2015-06-29 |29 June || 05:42 |[[Ramechhap District|Ramechhap]] |5.0 | | | |- |25 |2015-07-02 |2 July || 07:41 |Sindhupalchowk |5.0 | | | |- |} {{notelist}} ==Notes== :1.{{note|datanote}} The list uses data from National Seismological Centre of Nepal, not of US Geological survey.The magnitude is Local Magnitude. :2. {{note|aftershock}}The earthquake of 12th May 2015 was an aftershock of [[April 2015 Nepal earthquake|Gorkha earthquake]] and not a separate earthquake. :3. {{note|timenote}} All times shown below (including the ones for Tibet) are in [[Nepal Standard Time]] and in [[24-hour clock|24-hour format]]. Seconds are not shown in all times below. :4. {{note|datenote}} All dates are in the DD Month Year format ([[Date format by country#Legends|Little-endian]]). :5. {{note|datanote}} Please note that a significant number of aftershocks are missing in this list for the date between 27 April and 12 May. ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == * [https://earthquake.usgs.gov/ USGS Earthquake Hazards Program] * [http://www.seismonepal.gov.np National Seismological Centre, Nepal] {{2015 Nepal earthquake}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Aftershocks of April 2015 Nepal earthquake}} [[Category:2015 Nepal earthquake]] [[Category:Lists of earthquakes|Nepal 2015]] [[Category:Nepal-related lists]] [[Category:2015 in Nepal]] [[Category:Earthquakes in Nepal|2015, aftershocks]] [[Category:Natural disasters in Bihar]]

page.title: List of members of the National Academy of Sciences (Applied physical sciences)
List of things named after James Clerk Maxwell

revision.text:
This is a list of things named for [[James Clerk Maxwell]].
==Science== *[[Einstein–Maxwell–Dirac equations]] *[[Maxwell–Bloch equations]] * [[Maxwell's discs]] * [[Maxwell's theorem]] * Maxwell's Wheel * [[Maxwell's fisheye]] lens
===Electromagnetism=== *[[Maxwell–Wagner–Sillars polarization]] * Maxwell–Wien bridge, see Maxwell bridge * [[Maxwell bridge]] * [[Maxwell coil]] * [[Maxwell displacement current]] * [[Maxwell's equations]] (electromagnetism) ** [[Maxwell–Proca equation]] ** [[Ampère-Maxwell equation|Maxwell–Ampere law]] * The [[maxwell (unit)|maxwell]] (Mx), a compound derived [[CGS]] unit measuring [[magnetic flux]]<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ApFfBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA81#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=A Dictionary of Scientific Units: Including dimensionless numbers and scales |publisher=Springer |accessdate=12 June 2017 |isbn=9789400941113 |date=2012-12-06 }}</ref> * [[Maxwell tensor]], also [[Maxwell stress tensor]]
===Thermodynamics and kinetic theory=== * [[Maxwell–Boltzmann statistics]] ** [[Maxwell–Boltzmann distribution]] (statistical thermodynamics), also known as Maxwellian curve, or Maxwellian for short. *** [[Maxwell–Jüttner distribution]] * [[Maxwell–Stefan diffusion]] * [[Maxwell's relations]] (thermodynamics) * [[Maxwell's thermodynamic surface]] * [[Maxwell's demon]], a thought experiment in statistical physics *[[Maxwell construction]] *Maxwell equal area rule, see Maxwell construction * [[Maxwell speed distribution]] * Maxwell distribution, see Maxwell–Boltzmann distribution
===Solid mechanics=== * [[Maxwell material]] * Maxwell model of elasticity, see Maxwell material ** [[Upper convected Maxwell model]] ** [[Generalized Maxwell model]]
===Astronomy=== *[[12760 Maxwell]], an asteroid * [[Maxwell Montes]], a mountain range on [[Venus]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www2.jpl.nasa.gov/magellan/guide8.html |title=The Magellan Venus Explorer's Guide, Chapter 8, What's in a Name? |publisher=JPL/NASA |accessdate=12 June 2017 }}</ref> * The [[Maxwell Gap]] in the [[Rings of Saturn]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://photojournal.jpl.nasa.gov/catalog/PIA09857 |title=PIA09857: Maxwell's Namesake |publisher=JPL/NASA |accessdate=1 July 2013}}</ref> * [[Maxwell (crater)]]
===Optics=== *[[Maxwellian view]], a method of illuminating the eye by focusing an image at the plane of the pupil<ref>{{Cite journal|jstor = 1417947|title = The Use and Calibration of the 'Maxwellian View' in Visual Instrumentation|journal = The American Journal of Psychology|volume = 67|issue = 3|pages = 530–532|last1 = Leibowitz|first1 = Herschel|year = 1954}}</ref>
===Neuroscience=== *[[Maxwell's Spot]], a reddish spot seen in the centre of a visual field when a white surface is viewed through a dichroic filter transmitting red and blue lights. In 1856, Maxwell observed a dark spot in the blue region of a prismatic spectrum. The spot moved with his eye but disappeared upon looking elsewhere in the spectrum. He concluded that the spot was entoptic, being produced by a localized reduction of retinal illuminance that resulted from absorption of blue light by the yellow macular pigment, as the combined effects of the macular pigment and the distribution of short wavelength cones results in the [[fovea centralis]] having a lower sensitivity to blue light.
==Others== * The [[James Clerk Maxwell Telescope]], the largest [[Submillimetre astronomy|submillimetre]]-wavelength astronomical [[telescope]] in the world, with a diameter of {{convert|15|m|ft}}<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.clerkmaxwellfoundation.org/Newsletter_2013_Spring.pdf |title=The James Clerk Maxwell Telescope |publisher=James Clerk Maxwell Foundation |accessdate=12 June 2017 }}</ref> * The James Clerk Maxwell Building of the [[University of Edinburgh]], housing the schools of mathematics, physics and [[meteorology]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ph.ed.ac.uk/about/locations/jcmb |title=James Clerk Maxwell Building (JCMB) |publisher=University of Edinburgh |accessdate=1 July 2013}}</ref> * The James Clerk Maxwell building at the Waterloo campus of [[King's College London]], in commemoration of his time as Professor of Natural Philosophy at King's from 1860 to 1865. The university also has a chair in Physics named after him, and a society for undergraduate physicists.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kcl.ac.uk/aboutkings/history/famouspeople/jamesclerkmaxwell.aspx |title=James Clerk Maxwell |publisher=King's College London |accessdate=1 July 2013}}</ref> * The James Clerk Maxwell Centre of the [[Edinburgh Academy]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/education/dafty-genius-honoured-at-last-by-his-alma-mater-1-724315#axzz3qtY34nFS |title= 'Dafty' genius honoured at last by his alma mater |publisher=The Scotsman |accessdate=12 June 2017 }}</ref> * The Maxwell Centre at the [[University of Cambridge]], dedicated to academia-industry interactions in Physical Sciences and Technology.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.maxwell.cam.ac.uk |title=Maxwell Centre |publisher= University of Cambridge |accessdate=6 May 2016}}</ref> * [[James Clerk Maxwell Prize in Plasma Physics]] of the [[American Physical Society]]<ref>[http://www.aps.org/programs/honors/prizes/maxwell.cfm James Clerk Maxwell Prize for Plasma Physics], accessed 15 Nov 2013.</ref> * [[IEEE/RSE Wolfson James Clerk Maxwell Award]]<ref>[http://www.ieee.org/about/awards/medals/maxwell.html IEEE/RSE Wolfson James Clerk Maxwell Award], accessed 26 Nov 2013.</ref> * [http://www.maxwell.ac.uk/ Maxwell Institute for Mathematical Sciences] at the Universities of Edinburgh and Heriot-Watt * [http://www.clerkmaxwellfoundation.org/ James Clerk Maxwell Foundation] * [http://www.maxwellyear2006.org/ Maxwell Year 2006], website celebrating the 175th anniversary of his birth * Nvidia [[Maxwell (microarchitecture)|Maxwell]], a [[Graphics processing unit|GPU]] architecture released in 2014.<ref>https://web.archive.org/web/20140218145134/http://www.anandtech.com/show/7764/the-nvidia-geforce-gtx-750-ti-and-gtx-750-review-maxwell</ref> *Maxwell (Almighty God). The God mentioned throughout the Tales of Franchise. The Almighty Being in the story is named after him and places him on a pedastal as the Lord of Creation, making appearances in Tales of Phantasia, Tales of Phantasia 2, Tales of Eternia, Tales of Symphonia, Tales of Symphonia:Dawn of a new World, Tales of Xillia, and Tales of Xillia 2.
==See also== [[Maxwellian (disambiguation)|Maxwellian]]
==Footnotes== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Lists of things named after physicists|M]] [[Category:James Clerk Maxwell]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox mineral | name = Maucherite | boxwidth = | boxbgcolor = | image = Cubanite-Maucherite-Valleriite-199921.jpg | imagesize = 260px | alt = | caption = Cubanite-Maucherite-Valleriite | category = Arsenide mineral | formula = Ni11As8 | molweight = | strunz = 2.AB.15 | dana = | system = [[Tetragonal]] | class = Trapezohedral (422)
(same [[H-M symbol]]) | symmetry = ''P4''1212, ''P4''3212 | unit cell = | color = grey to reddish silver white | colour = | habit = | twinning = | cleavage = | fracture = | tenacity = | mohs = 4.5-5.5 | luster = | streak = grayish black | diaphaneity = | gravity = 6.9-7.3 | density = | polish = | opticalprop = | refractive = | birefringence = | pleochroism = | 2V = | dispersion = | extinction = | length fast/slow = | fluorescence = | absorption = | melt = | fusibility = | diagnostic = | solubility = | impurities = | alteration = | other = | prop1 = | prop1text = | references = [https://www.mineralienatlas.de/lexikon/index.php/MineralData?mineral=Maucherite Mineralienatlas] }} '''Maucherite''' is a grey to reddish silver white [[nickel arsenide]] mineral. It crystallizes in the [[tetragonal]] [[crystal system]]. It occurs in [[hydrothermal]] veins alongside other nickel arsenide and sulfide minerals. It is metallic and opaque with a [[Mohs hardness|hardness]] of 5 and a [[specific gravity]] of 7.83. It is also known as placodine and Temiskamite. The unit cell is of symmetry group ''P4''1212 or ''P4''3212. It has the [[chemical formula]]: Ni11As8 and commonly contains copper, iron, cobalt, antimony, and sulfur as impurities. It was discovered in 1913 in Eisleben, [[Germany]] and was named after Wilhelm Maucher (1879–1930), a [[Germany|German]] mineral collector. == References == {{commons category|Maucherite}} {{Reflist}} {{Refbegin}} *[http://www.mindat.org/min-2599.html Mindat localities] * {{Cite book |first=Walter |last=Schumann |series=BLV Bestimmungsbuch |title=Mineralien aus aller Welt |edition=2 |year=1991 |isbn=3-405-14003-X |pages=223 }} {{Refend}} [[Category:Nickel minerals]] [[Category:Arsenide minerals]] [[Category:Tetragonal minerals]] {{mineral-stub}}

revision.text:
In [[fluid dynamics]], the [[fluid]] flow is often decomposed into a '''mean flow''' – and [[deviation (statistics)|deviation]]s from the [[mean]]. The [[averaging]] can be done either in space or in time, or by [[ensemble average|ensemble averaging]].
==Example== Calculation of the mean flow may often be as simple as the [[mathematical mean]]: simply add up the given flow rates and then divide the final figure by the number of initial readings.
For example, given two [[Discharge (hydrology)|discharges]] (''Q'') of 3 m³/s and 5 m³/s, we can use these flow rates ''Q'' to calculate the mean flow rate ''Q''<sub>mean</sub>. Which in this case is ''Q''<sub>mean</sub> = 4 m³/s.
==See also== * [[Generalized Lagrangian mean]]
==References== * {{Citation | title=Wave interactions and fluid flows | first=Alex D. D. | last=Craik | publisher=Cambridge University Press | year=1988 | isbn=978-0-521-36829-2 }} * {{Citation | title=A first course in turbulence | first1=Hendrik | last1=Tennekes | author1-link=Hendrik Tennekes | first2=John L. | last2=Lumley | author2-link=John L. Lumley | publisher=MIT Press | year=1972 | isbn=978-0-262-20019-6 }}
{{fluiddynamics-stub}}
[[Category:Fluid dynamics]]

{{Infobox rocket <!----Image (optional)----> |image =Ham Launch - GPN-2000-001007 (cropped).jpg |imsize = 100 |caption =[[Mercury-Redstone 2]] launch carrying [[Ham the Chimp|Ham]] (chimpanzee), Jan 31, 1961 <!----Core parameters (required)----> |name =Mercury-Redstone Launch Vehicle |function = [[Human-rated]] [[sub-orbital]] [[launch vehicle]] |manufacturer =[[Chrysler Corporation]] |country-origin = United States <!----Dimensions (required)----> |height = 25.41 [[Metre|m]] <!--height of the rocket in metres, required--> |alt-height = 83.38 [[Foot (length)|ft]] <!--height of the rocket in feet, optional--> |diameter = 1.78 m <!--core diameter in metres, required--> |alt-diameter = 5.83 ft <!--core diameter in feet, optional--> |mass = 30,000 [[Kilogram|kg]] <!--mass of rocket in kilograms, required--> |alt-mass = 66,000 [[Pound (mass)|lb]] <!--mass of rocket in pounds, optional--> |stages = 1 <!--number of stages, not including boosters--> |payloads = Mercury spacecraft |capacities = <!--insert one of the following templates for each payload:--> {{Infobox Rocket/Payload |location = sub-orbital trajectory <!--Target orbit/trajectory, required--> |kilos = 1,800 kg <!--Payload mass in kilograms, required--> |pounds = 4,000 lb <!--Payload mass in pounds, optional--> }} <!----Launch history (required)----> |status = Retired |sites = [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Launch Complex 5|Launch Complex 5]], [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station|Cape Canaveral, Florida]] |launches = 6 |success = 5 |fail = 1 |first = November 21, 1960 |last = July 21, 1961 <!--Stages/boosters (optional)--> |stagedata = <!--insert one of the following templates for each stage:--> {{Infobox Rocket/Stage |type = stage <!--booster or stage--> |stageno = Single <!--position of stage in rocket, spelled out (eg. First, Second, etc), required--> |length = <!--length of a single booster/stage, optional--> |diameter = <!--diameter of a single booster/stage, optional--> |empty = <!--empty mass of a single booster/stage, optional--> |gross = <!--gross (fueled) mass of a single booster/stage, optional--> |engines = 1 [[Rocketdyne]] [[A-7 (rocket engine)|A-7]] <!--number and type of engines used on each individual booster/stage, required--> |thrust = 350 [[Newton (unit)|kN]] <!--thrust provided by a single booster/stage in kN, required--> |alt-thrust = 78,000 [[Pound-force|lb<sub>f</sub>]] <!--thrust provided by a single booster/stage in pounds-force, optional--> |SI = 215 sec <!--specific impulse of an individual booster/stage, in secs, optional--> |burntime = 143.5 seconds <!--burn time, required--> |fuel = [[LOX]]/[[ethyl alcohol]] <!--fuel used in stage/boosters, required--> }} }}
The '''Mercury-Redstone Launch Vehicle''', designed for [[NASA]]'s [[Project Mercury]], was the first American manned [[booster (rocketry)|space booster]]. It was used for six [[sub-orbital]] Mercury flights from 1960–61; culminating with the launch of the first, and 11 weeks later, the second American (and the second and third humans) in space. The four subsequent Mercury [[human spaceflight]]s used the more powerful [[Atlas LV-3B|Atlas booster]] to enter [[low Earth orbit]].
A member of the [[Redstone (rocket family)|Redstone rocket family]], it was derived from the [[U.S. Army]]'s [[PGM-11 Redstone|Redstone]] [[ballistic missile]] and the [[multistage rocket|first stage]] of the related [[Jupiter-C]] launch vehicle; but to [[Human-rating certification|human-rate]] it, the structure and systems were modified to improve safety and reliability.
== Modifications from the Redstone missile==
[[Image:Redstone-jupiterc-mercuryredstone-compared.jpg|thumb|left|180px|Comparison of Mercury-Redstone (right) with Redstone missile and Jupiter-C]]NASA chose the [[U.S. Army]]'s Redstone [[Liquid-fuel rocket|liquid-fueled]] ballistic missile for its suborbital flights as it was the oldest one in the US fleet, having been active since 1953 and had<ref>''This New Ocean'', p. 122.</ref> many successful test flights.<ref name="The Mercury-Redstone Project p. 2-2">''The Mercury-Redstone Project'', p. 2-2, 3-1.</ref>
The standard military Redstone lacked sufficient thrust to lift a Mercury capsule into the ballistic suborbital trajectory needed for the project;<ref name="The Mercury-Redstone Project p. 2-2"/> however, the first stage of the [[Jupiter-C]], which was a modified Redstone with lengthened tanks, could carry enough propellant to reach the desired trajectory. Therefore, this Jupiter-C first stage was used as the starting point for the Mercury-Redstone design.<ref>''The Mercury-Redstone Project'', p. 2-2, 3-1, 4-39 to 4-41.</ref> The Jupiter-C's engine, however, was being phased out by the Army, so to avoid potential complications such as parts shortages or design revisions, the Mercury-Redstone designers chose the [[Rocketdyne]] A-7 engine used on the latest military Redstones.<ref>''The Mercury-Redstone Project'', p. 4-41, 9-5.</ref> Hans Paul and William Davidson, propulsion engineers at the [[Army Ballistic Missile Agency]] (ABMA), were assigned the task of modifying the A-7 to be safe and reliable for manned flights.
During 1959, most of ABMA were preoccupied with the Saturn project, but those engineers who could find enough free time in their schedule were invited to work on man-rating the Jupiter-C. As a starting point, the most obvious step was getting rid of its staging capability as the Mercury-Redstone would not utilize upper stages. Many of the more advanced Jupiter-C components were also removed for reliability reasons or because they were not necessary for Project Mercury.
The standard Redstone was fueled with a 75 percent [[ethyl alcohol]] 25 percent water solution, essentially the same propellants as the V-2, but the Jupiter-C first stage had used [[hydyne]] fuel, a blend of 60 percent [[unsymmetrical dimethylhydrazine]] (UDMH) and 40 percent [[diethylenetriamine]] (DETA).<ref>''The Mercury-Redstone Project'', p. 2-2.</ref> This was a more powerful fuel than ethyl alcohol, but it was also more toxic,<ref>''The Mercury-Redstone Project'', p. 3-2, 4-42.</ref> which could be hazardous for an astronaut in a launch pad emergency.<ref>''The Mercury-Redstone Project'', p. 9-6.</ref> Furthermore, hydyne had never been used with the new A-7 engine.<ref>''The Mercury-Redstone Project'', p. 4-42.</ref> The Mercury-Redstone designers rejected hydyne and returned to the standard ethyl alcohol fuel. The lengthened propellant tanks were thus also necessary in lieu of using more powerful fuel.<ref>''The Mercury-Redstone Project'', p. 2-2, 3-2, 4-42.</ref>
Use of alcohol created a problem with the Mercury-Redstone in that the graphite thrust vector vanes could be eroded due to the significantly longer burn time, hence NASA put out a requirement that the launch vehicles needed high quality vanes.
Because Mercury-Redstone had larger propellant tanks than the Redstone missile, an additional nitrogen bottle was added for tank pressurization, and an extra [[hydrogen peroxide]] tank for powering the turbopump due to the longer burn time.
The most important change in making the Mercury-Redstone a suitable vehicle for an astronaut was the addition of an automatic in-flight abort sensing system.<ref>''The Mercury-Redstone Project'', p. 3-2, 9-3.</ref> In an emergency where the rocket was about to suffer a catastrophic failure, an abort would activate the [[launch escape system]] attached to the Mercury capsule, which would rapidly eject it from the booster. Either the astronaut or the ground controllers could initiate an abort manually,<ref>''The Mercury-Redstone Project'', p. 5-10, 5-11, 9-4.</ref> but some potential failures during flight might lead to disaster before an abort could be manually triggered.<ref>''The Mercury-Redstone Project'', p. 5-2, 9-4.</ref>[[Image:Mercury-Redstone Exploded View.gif|thumb|left|300px|Exploded view]]
The Mercury-Redstone's automatic in-flight abort sensing system solved this problem by monitoring the rocket's performance during flight. If it detected an anomaly which might threaten the astronaut, such as loss of flight control, engine thrust, or electrical power, it would automatically abort, shutting down the engine and activating the capsule's escape system.<ref>''The Mercury-Redstone Project'', p. 5-1, 5-2, 9-4.</ref> The abort system could not shut off the engine until at least 30 seconds after liftoff in order to prevent a malfunctioning launch vehicle from coming down on or near the pad; during the initial 30 seconds, only the Range Safety Officer could terminate the flight.<ref>''The Mercury-Redstone Project'', p. 3-5, 5-10.</ref> Review of flight data from the more than 60 Redstone and Jupiter C launches since 1953 was used to analyze the most likely failure modes of this launch vehicle family. In the interest of simplicity, the abort sensing system had to be kept as simple as possible and only monitor parameters that were vital to booster operation. An automatic abort could be triggered by any of the following conditions, all of which could be indicative of a catastrophic launch vehicle malfunction:
*Pitch, yaw, or roll angle deviating too far from the programmed flight profile,<ref>''The Mercury-Redstone Project'', p. 5-3, 5-6, 5-17, 5-19.</ref> *Pitch or yaw angle changing too rapidly,<ref>''The Mercury-Redstone Project'', p. 5-3, 5-6, 5-17, 5-23.</ref> *Pressure in the engine's combustion chamber falling below a critical level,<ref>''The Mercury-Redstone Project'', p. 5-3, 5-6.</ref> *Loss of electrical power for the flight control system,<ref>''The Mercury-Redstone Project'', p. 5-3, 5-6, 5-17.</ref> or *Loss of general electrical power (including power for the abort sensing system itself), which could indicate a catastrophic failure.<ref>''The Mercury-Redstone Project'', p. 5-3, 5-6, 5-10.</ref>
Instant abort capability was important because certain failure modes such as loss of thrust upon liftoff (for example the third Redstone test flight in May 1954) could result in an immediate catastrophic situation. Other failure modes such as deviation from the proper flight path or a drop in engine chamber pressure during ascent did not necessarily present an immediate risk to the astronaut's safety and he could either initial a manual abort by pulling a lever in the capsule to activate the Launch Escape System or ground control could send a command to activate it.
The range safety system was modified slightly in that a three-second delay would take place between engine cutoff and missile destruct so as to give the escape tower enough time to pull the capsule away.<ref>''The Mercury-Redstone Project'', p. 4-39, 4-43, 9-7.</ref>[[Image:Mercury-Redstone Booster Units.gif|thumb|left|180px|Schematic view]]
The most visible difference between the Jupiter-C first stage and the Mercury-Redstone was in the section just below the Mercury capsule and above the propellant tanks. This section was known as the ''aft section'', a term which was inherited from the military Redstone. (The actual rear end of the rocket was called the ''tail section''.) The aft section held most of the Mercury-Redstone's electronics and instrumentation, including the guidance system, as well as the adapter for the Mercury capsule.<ref>''The Mercury-Redstone Project'', p. 4-5, 4-6, 9-6.</ref> In the military Redstone and the Jupiter-C first stage, when the rocket had burned out, its lower portion, containing the rocket engine and propellant tanks, would separate from the aft section and be discarded, and the aft section, with its guidance system, would direct the top half of the rocket during its unpowered ballistic flight. However, in the Mercury-Redstone, the aft section was permanently attached to the lower portion of the rocket.<ref>''The Mercury-Redstone Project'', p. 3-2, 4-40.</ref> When the rocket had shut down, the Mercury capsule would separate from the aft section and would rely on its own guidance.
Other changes were made to improve the Mercury-Redstone's reliability. The standard Redstone's ST-80 [[inertial guidance system]] was replaced in the Mercury-Redstone with the simpler LEV-3 autopilot. The LEV-3, whose design dated back to the German [[V-2]] missile, was not as sophisticated or as precise as the ST-80, but it was accurate enough for the Mercury mission and its simplicity made it more reliable.<ref>''The Mercury-Redstone Project'', p. 3-2, 9-7.</ref> A special instrument compartment was built in the "aft section" to hold the most important instrumentation and electronics, including the guidance system, the abort and destruct systems, the [[telemetry]] instrumentation, and the electrical power supplies. To reduce the chance of failure in this equipment, this compartment was cooled before launch and kept pressurized during flight.<ref>''The Mercury-Redstone Project'', p. 4-5, 4-41.</ref>
The fuel prevalves were deleted from the Mercury-Redstone in the interest of improved reliability, since if they closed during a launch, an abort condition could be triggered. On the three unmanned flights, it was discovered that the Mercury-Redstone exhibited a roll transient of 8° per second versus 4° for the Redstone missile. Although this was below the 12° per second roll transient required to trigger an abort, the roll rate sensor was removed from the two manned flights to reduce the chances of an accidental abort (the booster still retained the roll attitude angle sensor which would be triggered at 10°).
Mercury-Redstone 1A and Mercury-Redstone 2 both experienced overacceleration in flight, the former due to a problem with an accelerometer, the latter due to a problem with the LOX regulator which oversupplied the engine with oxidizer and caused thrust termination to occur 1.2 seconds early. The ASIS system activated and the escape tower yanked the capsule away, subjecting its [[chimpanzee]] passenger to high G loads. The third flight, Mercury-Redstone BD, was designed as an engineering test to correct these problems before the booster could be considered man-rated.
The space between the pressurized instrument compartment and the capsule was originally intended to hold a parachute recovery system for the rocket, but it had been left empty after this system was abandoned. The three unmanned Mercury-Redstone flights exhibited high vibration levels and structural bending in the adapter area, so [[Alan Shepard]]'s flight included 340 pounds of lead-infused plastic in the adapter section along with additional bracing and stiffeners. After Shepard still reported noticeable vibration during launch, [[Gus Grissom]]'s booster included even more ballast. The Atlas booster used for orbital Mercury flights had also experienced this issue, but with more catastrophic results as [[Mercury-Atlas 1]] was destroyed in-flight due to structural failure caused by excessive flexing at the point where the booster mated with the capsule adapter.<ref>''The Mercury-Redstone Project'', p. 3-2, 4-5, 4-21, 4-41.</ref>
In total, some 800 modifications were made to the Redstone design in the process of adapting it for the Mercury program. The process of man-rating Redstone was so extensive that NASA quickly found themselves not using an off-the-shelf rocket, but what was in effect a completely new one and thus negating all of the hardware and flight test data from previous Redstone and Jupiter-C launches. This created a series of disputes between Von Braun's team at ABMA and NASA, as the former preferred simply making the abort system as foolproof as possible so as to guarantee that the astronaut would be bailed out of a malfunctioning launch vehicle, while the latter favored maximum booster reliability to minimize the chance of aborts happening at all.
== Proposed parachute recovery system ==
The Mercury-Redstone designers originally planned for the rocket to be recovered by parachute after its separation from the Mercury capsule. This was the first significant effort to develop a recoverable launch vehicle and the first to reach the testing phase.<ref>''The Mercury-Redstone Project'', p. 6-22, 6-23.</ref>
The recovery system, at the top of the rocket, would have used two stages of parachutes. In the first stage, a single parachute, {{convert|17|ft|m}} in diameter, would stabilize the rocket's fall and slow its descent. This parachute would then draw out a set of three main parachutes, each {{convert|67|ft|m}} across. The rocket would come down in the Atlantic Ocean, to be recovered by ship.<ref>''The Mercury-Redstone Project'', p. 6-29, 6-30.</ref>
To determine the feasibility of this system, several tests were performed on full-sized Redstones, including water impact and flotation tests, and an exercise at sea in which a floating Redstone was picked up by a Navy recovery ship. All these tests showed recovery of the rocket to be workable.<ref>''The Mercury-Redstone Project'', p. 6-33 to 6-39.</ref> Further development was halted, however, due to lack of funding, so the parachute system was not tested.<ref>''The Mercury-Redstone Project'', p. 6-23.</ref>
== Flights ==
Mercury-Redstone flights were designated with the prefix "MR-". Confusingly, the Mercury-Redstone boosters used for these flights were designated in the same way, usually with different numbers. (In photographs, this designation can sometimes be seen on the rocket's tail end.) Two rockets, MR-4 and MR-6, were never flown. Although there had been rumors that NASA in the very beginning of Project Mercury had intended to launch each astronaut on a suborbital mission before beginning orbital Atlas flights, they only purchased eight Mercury-Redstone boosters, one of which was damaged in the unsuccessful MR-1 launch and not reused, and another used for the MR-BD flight (the original schedule was for one unmanned Mercury-Redstone flight, one chimpanzee flight, and six manned flights). Since Alan Shepard and Gus Grissom's flights were successful and since the Soviet Union had flown two orbital manned space flights by the late summer of 1961, there was no need to continue with Redstone missions.<ref>''The Mercury-Redstone Project'', p. 6-3, 8-1.</ref>
{| class="wikitable" border="1" |- !Flight designation !Rocket designation !Launch date !Comments |- |[[Mercury-Redstone 1|MR-1]] |MR-1 |November 21, 1960 |Empty capsule; launch abort; rocket shut down at liftoff due to electrical fault |- |[[Mercury-Redstone 1A|MR-1A]] |MR-3 |December 19, 1960 |Empty capsule |- |[[Mercury-Redstone 2|MR-2]] |MR-2 |January 31, 1961 |Carried chimpanzee [[Ham the Chimp|Ham]] |- |[[Mercury-Redstone BD|MR-BD]] |MR-5 |March 24, 1961 |Empty nonfunctional "[[Boilerplate (spaceflight)|boilerplate]]" capsule |- |[[Mercury-Redstone 3|MR-3]] |MR-7 |May 5, 1961 |Carried astronaut [[Alan Shepard]] |- |[[Mercury-Redstone 4|MR-4]] |MR-8 |July 21, 1961 |Carried astronaut [[Gus Grissom]] |}
==Gallery== {{Gallery |width=300 |File:Mercury-Redstone on Redstone Test Stand MSFC-9306795.jpg|Mercury-Redstone prior to test-firing in the Redstone Test Stand at Marshall Space Flight Center, Alabama |File:Mercury-Redstone booster at MSFC with officials.jpg|[[Marshall Space Flight Center|MSFC]] Mercury-Redstone Project Manager [[Joachim Kuettner]] (l) and center officials host MR-4 astronaut Gus Grissom (6th from l). |File:Mercury Redstone 3 Prelaunch Activities - GPN-2000-001006.jpg | MR-3 prelaunch activities April 21, 1961 at [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Launch Complex 5|LC-5]], [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station|Cape Canaveral]], Florida |File:Mercury-Redstone 3 Launch MR3-9.jpg| MR-3 launch May 5, 1961 (Shepard) |File:Mercury-Redstone 4 booster erection 61-MR4-45.jpg|MR-4 booster erection at LC-5 |File:Mercury-Redstone 4 Launch MSFC-6414824.jpg|MR-4 launch July 21, 1961 (Grissom) }}

[[Image:MichalAbramowicz.jpg|thumb|Michał Abramowicz]]
'''Michał Abramowicz''' (1884 – 1965) was an [[Azerbaijan SSR|Azerbaijani-Soviet]] [[geologist]] of [[Polish people|Polish]] origin. He was born and died in [[Baku]], the capital of [[Azerbaijan]] and was a member of the Academy of Sciences of Azerbaijan.
==External links== *[http://www.polonia-baku.org/abramowicz.html Biography]

page.title: Mission: Earth, Voyage to the Home Planet

revision.text:
{{Use American English|date=December 2013}} {{Use mdy dates|date=December 2013}} {{good article}} {{Infobox book | name = Mission: Earth | title_orig = | translator = | image = Mission Earth, Voyage to the Home Planet.jpg | caption = Book cover | authors = June A. English, [[Thomas David Jones]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | subject = [[Human spaceflight]] | genre = [[Non-fiction]] | publisher = [[Scholastic Corporation|Scholastic]] | pub_date = 1996 | english_pub_date = | media_type = Hardback | pages = 40 | isbn = 0-590-48571-7 | oclc = 32464949 | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = The Scholastic Encyclopedia of the U.S. at War (1998) }} '''''Mission: Earth, Voyage to the Home Planet''''' is a [[children's literature]] book by science writer June A. English and astronaut [[Thomas David Jones]] that was published in 1996 by [[Scholastic Corporation|Scholastic]]. Jones was among the crew members of the [[Space Shuttle Endeavour|Space Shuttle ''Endeavour'']] during an [[STS-59|eleven-day mission in space]], which was launched in April 1994 to study the ecological well-being of Earth using specialized radar technology. The book, which is illustrated with radar images and picturesque photographs, chronicles the mission and Jones' experiences of it.
''Mission: Earth, Voyage to the Home Planet'' received a generally favorable reception in media coverage and book reviewers. The ''[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]'' said, "The authors convey the awe and wonderment of seeing Earth from space and the intricate delicacy of the Earth's ecology".<ref name="oconnell" /> ''[[The Dallas Morning News]]'' said, "The astronaut's descriptions are vivid".<ref name="thurman" /> A review in ''[[Booklist]]'' was more critical; it said, "The authors try to cover too much in so few pages, and the narrative, with several focal points, becomes simplified at times".<ref name="steinhorn" /> ''[[School Library Journal]]'' wrote, "It provides a unique look at a new method of research and an opportunity for youngsters to read one scientist's account of what it's like to engage in this exciting field of endeavor".<ref name="elaine" /> The book was selected for inclusion in books ''Best Books for Children'',<ref name="best" /> and ''Adventuring With Books'',<ref name="adventuring" /> or educating youths about history by using children's literature works.
==Background== June A. English is an author who specializes in science writing.<ref name="kathryn">{{cite book|page=50|first=Kathryn I.|last= Matthew|last2=Kimbell-Lopez |first2=Kimberly|title=Reading Comprehension: Books and Strategies for the Elementary Curriculum|publisher=The Scarecrow Press, Inc|year=2003|isbn=0-8108-4752-3}}</ref> She has published works within the genre of children's literature.<ref name="feed" />
[[Thomas David Jones]] was a member of the [[United States Air Force]] prior to working for [[NASA]].<ref name="feed">{{cite news|title=Feed hunger for war with facts|issn=0744-6055|date=September 20, 1998 |work=[[The Orlando Sentinel]]|first=Nancy |last=Pate |page=F6|publisher=Sentinel Communications Co.}}</ref> As Jones was a United States federal employee at the time of the book's publication, he did not receive profits from sales of the work.<ref name="thurman">{{cite news|title=A space odyssey Astronaut shares stories with students in Denton County|first=Nita|last=Thurman|date=February 4, 1998 |work=[[The Dallas Morning News]]|page= 25A|publisher=The Dallas Morning News Company}}</ref> English and Jones later produced another collaborative work, ''Scholastic Encyclopedia of the United States at War'', which was published in 1998.<ref>{{cite news|title=3 kids' books tell tales of war, heroes|date=December 6, 1998 |first=Jerry |last=Johnston |issn=0745-4724|work=[[The Deseret News]]|location=[[Salt Lake City, Utah]]|page=E06|publisher=Deseret News Publishing Company}}</ref><ref name="Jones 2006">{{cite book|title=Sky Walking: An Astronaut's Memoir|last=Jones|first=Thomas D.|authorlink=Thomas David Jones|year=2006|publisher=HarperCollins|isbn=978-0-06-085152-1}}</ref> Jones wrote another book about his experiences in space, ''Sky Walking: An Astronaut's Memoir'', which was published in 2006.<ref name="Jones 2006"/><ref>{{cite journal|first=Charles D.|last=Haynes|journal=Science Books & Films|volume=42|issue=4|date=July 2006|page=162|title=Sky Walking|location=United States|issn=0098-342X}}</ref>
==Contents== [[File:Jones3436.jpg|thumb|[[Thomas David Jones]] (1996)]]
In ''Mission: Earth, Voyage to the Home Planet'', astronaut Thomas David Jones recounts his experiences studying the Earth during his first mission with the United States space agency NASA.<ref>{{oclc|32464949}}</ref> Jones' space mission lasted eleven days.<ref>{{cite book|pages=170, 641, 663|first=Linda L.|last= Homa|last2=Schreck |first2=Ann L. |last3=Hoebener |first3=Maureen|title=Elementary School Library Collection: A Guide to Books and Other Media, Phases 1-2-3|publisher=Brodart Co|year=1998|isbn=0-87272-114-0}}</ref> Jones was a member of the crew of the Space Shuttle ''Endeavour'', which left Earth in April 1994.<ref name="wandajmiller">{{cite book|last=Miller|first=Wanda J.|pages=106, 222|publisher=Libraries Unlimited|year=1998|isbn=978-1-56308-581-9|title=Teaching U.S. history through children's literature: post-World War II}}</ref> The mission was intended to provide the [[STS-59|Space Radar Lab]] with a view of the planet.<ref name="wandajmiller" /> By using three separate radar echoes, scientists were able to analyze a full image of the planet.<ref name="wandajmiller" /> The radar technology could penetrate obstructions, including clouds and thick outgrowth of trees.<ref name="wandajmiller" /> Another purpose of the mission was to analyze the ecological state of the planet and to take measurements of pollution caused by [[carbon monoxide]].<ref name="fenly" />
The book is based upon journal entries written by Jones during the mission.<ref name="thurman" /> He presents a typical NASA mission member's day-to-day experiences while living on the space shuttle.<ref name="elaine" /> Jones illustrates his account with photographs from his mission and pictures from the radar capture.<ref name="wandajmiller" /> He describes his observations while looking at the Earth from space, for example he says, "Maybe more than any other sight from space, lightning gives the decided impression that the Earth is alive, a living organism".<ref name="fenly">{{cite news|title=Let shooting comet catch your child's fancy|date=February 16, 1997 |first=Leigh |last=Fenly|work=[[The San Diego Union-Tribune]]|page=5, Section: Books|publisher=Union-Tribune Publishing Co.}}</ref> He described [[Aurora (astronomy)|aurora]] phenomena as, "shimmering fingers of green light reaching up from the dark ocean, an arc of light around the South Magnetic Pole".<ref name="thurman" /> June English provides contextual information about Jones' mission.<ref name="horn" />
==Reception==
''Mission: Earth, Voyage to the Home Planet'' received a positive review from journalist Rebecca O'Connell, who wrote in the ''[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]'', "The authors convey the awe and wonderment of seeing Earth from space and the intricate delicacy of the Earth's ecology".<ref name="oconnell" /> She said of the descriptive nature of the text, "Their descriptions of scientific phenomena read like revelations of mystic wonders. But this is not to say it is ponderous, not at all."<ref name="oconnell" /> O'Connell's review concluded, "The text is packed with fascinating information and humorous touches. Even children who are not ordinarily interested in space or ecology will be interested in this book, and aficionados will go ga-ga."<ref name="oconnell">{{cite news|last=O'Connell|first=Rebecca|date=November 10, 1996|issn=1068-624X|work=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]|page=G–11|title=Reading that's fun and fundamental}}</ref> Leigh Fenly of ''[[The San Diego Union-Tribune]]'' recommended the book, and said, "Science writer June English tracked the launch and adds perspective on how the mission will help scientists understand Earth, including its atmosphere, geology, ecology{{mdash}}and future".<ref name="fenly" /> Nita Thurman wrote for ''[[The Dallas Morning News]]'', "''Mission: Earth, A Journey to the Home Planet'' has dozens of color photos taken inside the shuttle and through its windows. The astronaut's descriptions are vivid."<ref name="thurman" /> ''[[Publishers Weekly]]'' wrote favorably of the book, saying, "Astronaut Jones's enthusiasm for his work is contagious; it shines through the text, making for a roundly enjoyable and informative read".<ref name="publishers">{{cite journal|journal=[[Publishers Weekly]]|year=1996|title=Mission: Earth|publisher=Reed Business Information, Inc|location=United States|issn=0000-0019}}</ref> ''Publishers Weekly'' recommended the book and said it is, "[w]ell-conceived and thoughtfully executed, this book deserves a wide audience."<ref name="publishers" />
{{quote box |width=25em | bgcolor=#c6dbf7 |align=left |halig=left | salign=right|quote="The authors convey the awe and wonderment of seeing Earth from space and the intricate delicacy of the Earth's ecology."|source= —''[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]''<ref name="oconnell" />}}
A review of the book by Ilana Steinhorn in ''[[Booklist]]'' was more critical. Steinhorn said, "The authors try to cover too much in so few pages, and the narrative, with several focal points, becomes simplified at times ... Still, the account is interesting, and the many high-quality, often breathtaking color photographs and radar images complement the text nicely".<ref name="steinhorn">{{cite journal|first=Ilana|last=Steinhorn|journal=[[Booklist]]|publisher=[[American Library Association]]|title=Mission: Earth|date=October 15, 1996|volume=93|page=415|location=United States|issn=0006-7385}}</ref> Elaine Fort Weischedel reviewed the book for ''[[School Library Journal]]'', and recommended it for teaching specific subject matter. She wrote, "Pollution patterns, shifting ocean currents, destruction of rain forests, and other environmental changes were the heart of Jones's project, and this book might be used more successfully to supplement the curriculum in those areas than in units on space flight per se".<ref name="elaine">{{cite journal|first=Elaine Fort |last=Weischedel |journal=[[School Library Journal]]|publisher=Library Journals LLC; [[Media Source, Inc.]]|title=Mission: Earth|volume=42|date=October 1996|page=130|location=United States|issn=0362-8930}}</ref> Weischedel said the book "provides a unique look at a new method of research and an opportunity for youngsters to read one scientist's account of what it's like to engage in this exciting field of endeavor".<ref name="elaine" /> ''[[Horn Book Review]]'' called the book "a uniquely personal account", and said it "features a crowded design, but the many color photographs throughout the text are fascinating".<ref name="horn">{{cite journal|journal=[[Horn Book Review]]|title=Mission: Earth|year=1996|publisher=The Horn Book, Inc; [[Media Source, Inc.]]|location=United States}}</ref>
''Mission: Earth, Voyage to the Home Planet'' is listed in the book ''Teaching U.S. history through children's literature: post-World War II'' by Wanda J. Miller as a resource for educating youth about history by using children's literature works.<ref name="wandajmiller" /> It is used in other such books, including ''Strategies That Work: Teaching Comprehension for Understanding and Engagement'' by Stephanie Harvey and Anne Goudvis,<ref>{{cite book|page=319|title=Strategies That Work: Teaching Comprehension for Understanding and Engagement|first=Stephanie|last= Harvey|last2=Goudvis |first2=Anne|publisher=Stenhouse Publishers|year=2007|isbn=978-1-57110-481-6}}</ref> ''Reading Comprehension: Books and Strategies for the Elementary Curriculum'' by Kathryn K. Matthew and Kimberly Kimbell-Lopez,<ref name="kathryn" /> and ''An Integrated Language Perspective in the Elementary School: An Action Approach'' by Christine Pappas, Barbara Zulandt Kiefer, and Linda S. Levstik.<ref>{{cite book|title=An Integrated Language Perspective in the Elementary School: An Action Approach|publisher=Allyn & Bacon|year=1998|isbn=0-8013-3055-6|first=Christine |last=Pappas|last2=Kiefer |first2=Barbara Zulandt |last3=Levstik |first3=Linda S.|page=79}}</ref> It was selected for inclusion in ''Best Books for Children'' by John Thomas Gillespie,<ref name="best">{{cite book|title=Best Books for Children: Preschool Through Grade 6 Seventh Edition|first=John Thomas |last=Gillespie|year=2001|page=1093|publisher=Libraries Unlimited|isbn=0-313-32068-3}}</ref> and ''Adventuring With Books'' by Kathryn Mitchell Pierce.<ref name="adventuring">{{cite book|page=7|title=Adventuring With Books: A Booklist for Pre-K-Grade 6|first=Kathryn Mitchell |last=Pierce|publisher=National Council of Teachers|year=2000|isbn=0-8141-0077-5}}</ref>
==See also==

Jones |authorlink2=Thomas David Jones |publisher=Scholastic Reference|year=1998|isbn=0-590-63421-6}} *{{cite book|title=Sky Walking: An Astronaut's Memoir|last=Jones|first=Thomas D.|authorlink=Thomas David Jones|year=2006|publisher=HarperCollins|isbn=978-0-06-085152-1}}

revision.text:
[[image:Otto Tetens in Samoa with Paramount chief Josefo Mataafa (1904).jpg|right|thumb|450px | Otto Tetens with Mataafa in Mulinuu, Samoa 1904]] '''Otto Tetens''' (26 September 1865, [[Rendsburg]], Germany – 15 February 1945, [[Teplitz-Schönau]]) was a German [[natural scientist]] with an [[astronomer]] background.
== Life == Tetens was the son of a high ranked police officer in [[Schleswig]], Northern Germany. He went to several universities for different [[natural science]] topics in [[Tübingen]], [[Munich]], [[Berlin]] and [[Kiel]]. After this period, he worked at the private astronomy observatory of Miklos Konkly-Thege in Ogyalla in Hungary. In 1891 he got his Doctor degree of Natural Science. He then worked at different institutes in astronomy such as the Deutsche Seewarte, [[Hamburg]], and the [[Observatory of Strasbourg]].<ref>Source: Family records now owned by C. Niggemann</ref>
From 1902 to 1905 Otto Tetens worked for the Royal Society of Science of Göttingen on a climate project in [[Samoa]], then a German colony. He founded the Apia Observatory in June 1902 at Mulinuu near the main town of [[Apia]]. After his time in Samoa, he went back to Germany and [[Göttingen]] to work on his reports for the previous three years and then took an occupation at the Royal Astronomy Observatory in [[Kiel]], Germany.<ref>Ergebnisse Der Arbeiten Des Samoa-Observatoriums ... II. Die Meteorologischen Registrierungen Der Jahre 1902-1906 ... Mit 3 Tafeln und 25 in Den Text Gedruckten FigurenReport Otto Tetens und Franz Linke</ref>
From 1909 to 1931 Tetens worked at the meteorological observatory in {{ill|Lindenberg (Tauche)|de|lt=Lindenberg}}, Germany (south-east of [[Berlin]]) as chief-observer. After retirement he moved to [[Bad Saarow]], some 10 km away from Lindenberg and lived at his house in [http://see27.d] Seestrasse] at the Lake Scharmützelsee.<ref>Hans Steinhagen: Lindenberger Himmelsjäger, published in Arkana-Verlag Göttingen</ref>
He died in 1945 while staying at a sanatorium in Teplitz-Schönau. His wife Dorothee Heimrod, daughter of the Council of the United States in Samoa and later Switzerland, moved back to the USA in 1947 and died 1962 in [[New York City]].
== Photography by Otto Tetens == During his time in Samoa, Otto Tetens took a great number of valuable and interesting photos of his time and the people of Samoa. These photos were exhibited in Germany and Samoa in 2004 and 2005.<ref>Samoa 1904, published by Christiane Niggemann 2004, Arkana-Verlag Göttingen</ref>
The photo with the paramount chief Josefo Mataafa shows the way Otto Tetens was living in Samoa: as a partner on the same level, with strong adoption of Samoan culture and habits. His houses for work and living at the Mulinuu observatory were built as Samoan fales, not as German wood houses. The photo was taken in 1904 by Otto Tetens.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== Christiane Niggemann (Hrsg.): Samoa 1904. Menschen, Landschaft und Kultur im Süd-Pazifik vor Hundert Jahren. Fotos von Otto Tetens in Samoa 1902–1905. Arkana-Verlag, Göttingen 2004 (Germany), {{ISBN|3-923257-05-8}}
Felix Lühning. "...Eine ausnehmende Zierde und Vortheil". Geschichte der Kieler Universitätssternwarte und ihrer Vorgängerinnen 1770–1950. Zwei Jahrhunderte Arbeit und Forschung zwischen Grenzen und Möglichkeiten. Neumünster: Wachholtz, 2007 (Habilitationsschrift, Fachbereich Mathematik der Universität Hamburg 2002).
Hans Steinhagen: Lindenberger Himmelsjäger – Miniaturen rund um das Observatorium. Arkana-Verlag, Göttingen 2011 (Germany), S. 70 ff
==External links== *[http://www.samoa1904.de ''Fotos von Otto Tetens in Samoa 1902-1905'']. Samoa 1904. Museum Bochum. {{de icon}} *[http://www.samoa1905.de ''Photos by Otto Tetens in Samoa 1902-1905'']. Samoa 1905. Exhibition in Apia. {{en icon}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Tetens, Otto}} [[Category:German astronomers]] [[Category:Natural scientists]] [[Category:1865 births]] [[Category:1945 deaths]] [[Category:German scientists]]

A '''physical test''' is a [[qualitative property|qualitative]] or [[Quantitative property|quantitative]] procedure that consists of determination of one or more characteristics of a given product, process or service according to a specified procedure.<ref>[[ASTM]] E 1301, Standard Guide for Proficiency Testing by Interlaboratory Comparisons</ref> Often this is part of an [[experiment]].
'''Physical testing''' is common in [[physics]], [[engineering]], and [[quality assurance]].
==Purposes== Physical testing might have a variety of purposes, such as: * if, or verify that, the requirements of a [[specification]], [[regulation]], or [[contract]] are met * Decide if a [[new product development]] program is on track: Demonstrate [[proof of concept]] * Demonstrate the utility of a proposed [[patent]] * Provide [[Technical standard|standard]] [[data]] for other scientific, engineering, and [[quality assurance]] functions * Validate suitability for end-use * Provide a basis for [[Technical communication]] * Provide a technical means of comparison of several options * Provide [[evidence]] in legal proceedings
==Performance testing== Some physical testing is ''performance testing'' which covers a wide range of engineering or functional evaluations where a material, product, or system is not specified by detailed material or component specifications. Rather, emphasis is on the final measurable performance characteristics. Testing can be a [[qualitative data|qualitative]] or [[Quantitative data|quantitative]] procedure. Many [[Acceptance testing]] protocols employ performance testing e.g. In the stress testing of a new design of chair.
===Examples of performance testing=== * Building and [[Construction]] Performance Testing * [[Fire protection]] ([[ASTM]] D176) * [[Packaging]] Performance ([[hazardous materials]], [[dangerous goods]], [[ASTM]] D4169) * Performance Index for [[Tire]]s ([[ASTM]] F538) * Performance Test Code on Compressors and Exhausters ([[ASME]] PTC 10 - 1997) * [[Personal protective equipment]] performance * Several [[Defense Standard]]s * Wear of Textiles ([[ASTM]] D123)
==Gallery== <gallery> File:Three point flexural test.jpg| [[Test fixture]] on [[universal testing machine]] File:US Navy 070409-N-3038W-002 Aviation Structural Mechanic 3rd Class Rene Tovar adjusts a connection point on a fixture hydraulic supply servo cylinder test station in the hydraulics shop aboard the Nimitz-class aircraft carrier U.jpg|Hydraulic system testing File:Drop test haz-mat.jpg|Drop test of [[shipping container]] for missile File:ISEE-C_(ISEE_3)_in_dynamic_test_chamber.jpg|Engineers in [[NASA]] dynamic test chamber File:Honda Fit - Impact Still.jpg| [[Crash test]] of car striking a wall File:Cmp test 10.jpg|Fire testing materials and structures </gallery>
==See also== * [[Environmental chamber]] * [[Test method]] *[[Independent test organization]]
==References== {{reflist}} * Pyzdek, T, "Quality Engineering Handbook", 2003, {{ISBN|0-8247-4614-7}} * Godfrey, A. B., "Juran's Quality Handbook", 1999, {{ISBN|007034003X}}
[[Category:Metrology]] [[Category:Measurement]] [[Category:Quality control]] [[Category:Tests]] [[Category:Product testing]]
